29162277.review:
Ahhh, the N64... While the controller looked like it was designed by aliens for people with more than two hands, the games it had and the way it utilized that controller cemented it into the hearts of gamers in all corners of Earth.

And when it came to the top FPS titles, there was GoldenEye... And then there was Turok.

Turok: Dinosaur Hunter was the first FPS I ever played, and it is one I have fond memories of. And while I loved the second in the series the most, I will never forget this game.

Story:

Oddly enough, the story was not told in-game, but was hinted at in manuals and other forms of media.

You play as Tal'Set Fireseed, a Native American from the Saquin Tribe as he is transported to Galyanna, The Lost Land, a land where time has literally NO meaning and is inhabited by all sorts of aliens, peoples, interdimensional beings and DINOSAURS.
However, this new world and ours are now under a terrible threat.
The Campaigner, a meglomaniacal cybernetic tyrant, has devealoped a superweapon that threatens not only The Lost Land, but also our world as well, as he masses an army of cyborgs and cybernetically-enhanced dinosaurs in a terrible plan of universal domination.
It is up to Tal'Set to become Turok, the Son Of Stone, and end the diobolical machinations of The Campaigner once and for all.

Gameplay:

I'll admit, the N64 verson was a lot harder to play, but this one is definitely better to control, though the difficulty is still there.

The game really does handle smoothly, and it does manage to feel fluid, without any hiccups at all.

The enemy AI is very notable, as they are vicious and can think cunningly and gang up on you, so be wary what you do.

Graphics:

Sadly, the graphics look very dated, but that is not imprtant to me. You can be a delicious cake even if the frosting looks as old as your granny running in terror in the rain. Even so, the graphics add to the charm, and to be honest, they aren't the worst.

Weapons:

There is an INSANE amount of weapons you can hold and carry, from the usual pistol, shotguns, assault rifle and bow, to a minigun, rocket and grenade launchers, a cannon that unleashes a NUCLEAR BLAST, and a fair bit more. Whatever you decide to tackle your enemies with, this game will give you those options.

Sound:

The sound has upgraded quite a bit since the N64 version, and while it does have moments where it could have been better, it is a far cry better than it once was, and the N64 version was pretty good for it's time.

Rating (1 being the best, 10 being the worst) 3.2 (Gold Rating, Four Stars out of Five)

This game is the best way to experience the original Turok, with the upgrades and better bells and whistles that you need. While some things could have used some work, this game is able to beat the issues to deliver one grand product and nostalgia trip.

29152950.review: Wow, holy fuck this game is as awesome as I remember it from when I was a kid. Its still a blast to play and this is a fantastically done remaster- theres really nothing else like it.

29151562.review:
Good old school FPS fun (1997 is old school right?).

Turok does not stray an inch from the tried and tested Doom formula: There's just about no in-game story, you run around, you shoot things (in this case "things" tend to be dinosaurs, aliens and robots), find secrets, and try to make your way from point A to point B in a series of increasingly complex levels. 

Fortunately, while it may not be the most innovative game of its generation, Turok does all those things pretty damn well. The levels are largely fun to explore, you have a fairly wide arsenal at your disposal and most (but not all) secrets aren't excessively obtuse to find. 

I would definitely consider this game to be a must-have for any fan of the genre who's already played the classics (Doom, Quake, Unreal) and who seeks something fresh to scratch that itch.  

It's also worth noting that Turok was originally meant to be played with a controller on an N64, so you may want to up that difficulty a notch if you're going to be using mouse+keyboard. 

Finally, if longevity is a worry, all I can say is that it took me somewhere around 10-11 hours to complete it blind and find the "main" secrets linked to an endgame unlockable. This was done in 'Hard' mode, which is not the hardest setting, so your experience may vary.

For those who like meaningless numbers I rate this game 7 Triceratops out of 10.

29128424.review:
Never assume a good game will stay good.

For about 75% of my playthrough, it felt like a given that I'd be giving this a positive review. Turok is a visually limited, dated game with next to no story, but it had a bouncy, almost Crash Bandicoot-esque feel to it that made the game feel surprisingly upbeat and unambiguously fun-for-fun's-sake in a way that very few FPSes manage. Even Doom is a bit bogged down in that regard with its demonic gloom and preoccupation with macho metal badassery. Plus you get to fight dinosaurs, which I don't think happens nearly enough in games, despite it seeming like an obvious match.

Buuut then the last two levels happened, and my goodwill dropped like a rock. I feel like the game's assets were planned and developed before they even thought about doing any level design, because while the last two levels have more unique enemy models than the rest of the game put together, the actual design of the levels are absolute crap. The penultimate level is crowded with way too many respawning enemies, no real visual direction so it's impossible to get any sort of instinct as to what's an exploratory path and what's a main path, and is filled with points of no return, especially after the halfway point where it basically turns into a totally different level. And the final level stacks hordes of overpowered enemies on top of making most of them respawn, is now almost completely linear, and drags on for FAR too long so that by the end of it even the two back-to-back final bosses were just an extra speed bump to the end credits.

The first 3/4 of the game is actually a lot of fun and made me wish that the other Turok games were available on Steam, but if they're anything like the last quarter of this game I wouldn't bother with them even if they were.

Having played this game for a few hours now, I can say that it shows its age in many respects (graphics, jumping puzzles, lives), but that is more than made up for by its excellent level design, weapon variety and enemy design. More importantly, the game is just fun to play: whether its shooting a dinosaur in the face using a shotgun with explosive shells, very fast paced gameplay (you have to move fast or you will be overwhelmed by respawning enemies), or general over-the-top nature, this game is a blast.

I will note that I hadn't played this game before purchasing it on sale for $4.99, but grew up in the era when it was released. This game might look too ugly for many to play nowadays, but those who overlook it will be overlooking a rough diamond of late 90's FPS's. Recommended. (But definitely wait for it to be on sale again!)

29108134.review:
Turok is exactly how I remember it from my childhood..but so much better now. There are alot of aspects of this game that I liked and very few that I didnt like about the game.

I'll start off listing the positives: 
+ Level design is amazingly crafted.
+ Enemies are unique which keep the game interesting from beginning to end.
+ Movement is fun and quick, great combination for a fps action game.
+ Steam achievements.
+ Nostalgic gameplay from my N64 days.

Here are some negatives that come to mind:
- FPS issues here and there. Shouldnt really be happening for a 20 year old game..
- Some minor glitches with the enviroment that made me die a couple times.
- Using cheats disables achievements, I just wanted to use purdy colors while I played!

Overall this is a remarkable game and I [b]do[/b] recommend it to anyone. I bought this game hoping to get some nostalgia and maybe play the first level or two but omg I didnt realize it was [i]this[/i] good!!!
My Rating: ★★★★☆

29106049.review: I played this game on the N64 back in the day, and I was happy to find that it's just as good today as it was back then. Some of the mechanics and level designs feel a bit dated, but that has to be expected from a game that's 20 years old. More importantly, it's still got that classic FPS feel that you'll remember fondly if you were gaming during the late 90s and early-to-mid 2000s. $20 does feel a bit steep for such an old game, but if you catch it on sale, you should definitely pick this one up.

29104971.review: a blast from the past, still as fresh as ever, money well spent and still hard as nails :) hope for more.....games were a lot more fun back then.

29104564.review:
You play as "Turok". Dont worry about memorizing his name because he's gonna remind you of it constantly. 

The game composes of 8 stages. Each stage has a number of keys to collect which unlocks the other stages.
Levels are not straight forward so you will have to explore alot. You may have to play some stages multiple times.

There are a variety of weapons. However some weapons share the same ammo. Which means some weapons become redundant. Or you end up wasting ammo that could have been used for a stronger weapon.
And some weapons look fancy and powerful but feel useless.

There are platforming sections. They are not terrible like Rise of the Triad 2013 for example. But certain jumps require extra precision since you cant see your feet to know how far from the edge you are.

Portals for bonus levels appear from time to time. They are not bad just boring.

You can only save at specific locations. There are checkpoint in between you can go through. You collect items for extra lives.

The game is not timed but you'll find yourself rushing because enemies respawn fast in some areas.

Game suffers from framerate drops. For such an old game with such a short view distance its kinda silly that it cant keep a smooth 60fps. 

Looking forward to Turok 2: Seeds of Evil remaster.

The animation is extremely smooth and very responsive. Playing any fps after this make me feel like a freakin slug on sedative.
Also i have to talk about the music..WHAT...THE...HELL! Don't get me wrong, the music is awful, it look like hardcore techno(especially the old city level), the kind of techno you would find in an underground pothead festival in middle of nederlands country.
Killing robot alien magical bi-dimensional dinosaurs at speed of light while listening to hardcore shitty techno is an experience i recommand to anyone, especially metheads.

29080956.review:
Une pièce d'art!

Un des meilleur fps jamais fait en solo avec beaucoup de plateforme, de secrets et d'énigmes.
Une ambiance hors du commun que ce soit sonore ou visuelle.
Une IA étonnante (certains ennemis peuvent s'attaquer entre eux parfois).
Une panoplie d'armes à tomber par terre! (sans compter les armes aliens...)
Une durée de vie colossale.

On appréciera en particulier le workshop et l'éditeur de niveau.
Il est possible de faire des choses superbes et certains mods améliorent fortement les textures en plus de la définition de base du jeu qui est passée en hd. (je conseille d'ailleurs fortement le mod iddqd_textures pour ça et le mod turok+ pour le gameplay)

A noter que certains niveaux ont été un peu modifiés sur cette version et si vous voulez les mêmes que la version de base qui est sortie sur n64, un mod est disponible pour ça. (original turok levels)

Les démonstrations de niveaux après avoir attendu à l'écran du menu du jeu ont disparu mais ce n'est pas bien grave.
La manette est parfaitement prise en charge et largement paramétrable pour la sensibilité.

Et enfin... l'épisode 2 (qui est aussi formidable) est en développement par le même développeur! ;)

29073960.review:
Ich schwelge in der Nostalgie Welle ;-)
Erst Shadow Warrior, dann DOOM, dann Shadow Warrior 2, dann Space Hulk Deathwing und dann, ja dann, ähh...

TUROK ? 
WER oder WAS ist Turok, wird sich so manch einer der jüngeren Generation von Spielern fragen.

Turok war ein Vorzeige-Shooter für das Nintendo 64 (ich glaube das war 1997) und damals habe ich das auf dem N64 gezockt bis das Modul glühte.

Das Remaster läuft super flüssig in 60fps, die Grafik wurde leicht aufgebohrt, die Sichtweite erhöht, die Steuerung angepasst (WASD) und hier und da ein paar Änderungen in den Levels vorgenommen. Mir macht es durch den Nostalgie Bonus verständlicherweise sehr viel Spass und ich denke, dass ich es an andere Spieler aus meiner Generation (80er 90er) bedingungslos empfehlen kann. Für alle anderen gilt, erst einmal ein paar Let's Plays anschauen und dann entscheiden. Einziger Kritikpunkt ist der für ein 20 Jahre altes Spiel etwas zu hohe Preis von 20€, zehn hätten es auch getan, aber ich will nicht meckern und erfreue mich daran mein geliebtes Turok in "guter Optik" und schön flüssig spielen zu können Juhu ;P 

Dabei gefällt mir besonders, dass ich immer noch die schön matschigen Texturen serviert bekomme und nicht viel an der Optik verändert wurde (ja, das ist mein voller Ernst), denn so bleibt das einzigartige Gefühl bestehen, was eben damals Spiele ausgemacht hat. Sie wirkten einfach eben noch wie Spiele, gerade wegen der nicht realistischen Grafik und erzeugten so oft eine morbide Stimmung, die heute nur durch bestimmte Lichteffekte und anderes Gedöns erzeugt werden können, aber belassen wir es dabei, ich verfalle ins Labern. Super wäre es noch, wenn das Remaster von Turok2 käme (gefiel mir persönlich noch besser als Teil 1), aber daran arbeiten Night Dive Studios ja.

Fazit: 
Empfehlung für alte Spiele-Hasen wie mich.
Alle anderen sollten sich erst durch Videos über das Spiel informieren und vielleicht noch auf einen Sale warten.

29066761.review:
I have no memory of the original game to compare against.
Still a solid game, but it definitely shows its N64 age.

Turok reminded me of playing classic PC shooters like Doom and Duke3D though. You glide through the levels at high speed and zap most of the bads without problem.
It's fun. It's a bit weird. It's very video gamey with mechanics like lives and earning more 100 coins-style. There are bonus stages, keys within levels that unlock new levels and frantic boss battles.

One of the great features is how ammo is doled out. You can hold just enough to prevent you from ever using one set of weapons, much less ever have enough to rely on a single gun for very long.
Plenty of puzzle platforming with instant death pitfalls can be annoying though, since death removes any bonus HP above 100 you may have earned.

Had fun though.

29050233.review:
Turok por muito tempo foi um dos jogos que eu mais queria ter, lembro que joguei pela primeira vez esse jogo no Nintendo 64 com uma fita alugada, eu achava esse jogo genial na época e considerava que esse jogo tinha os melhores gráficos que já tinha visto e as armas também eram bem diferentes do outros jogos que eu estava acostumado a jogar no computador como Doom, Duke Nukem 3D, Blood, Quake e Quake 2. Acredito que na época esse jogo me parecia mais revolucionário que o próprio 007 Goldeneye que na época era considerado o melhor FPS do Nintendo 64. 

É com toda certeza um jogo difícil, mesmo jogando na menor dificuldade passamos por alguns sofrimentos, por exemplo: Só é possível avançar no jogo na medida em que encontramos as chaves para desbloquear os portais, o problema é que essas chaves ficam escondidas em pontos secretos dos mapas que são enormes, junto a isso ainda temos um número limitado de vidas no jogo. O que é uma droga, porque em muitas partes teremos que pular de um lugar para outro e sempre acabamos caindo e perdendo vidas que são difíceis de conseguir recuperar depois, mas isso só contribui para que o jogo seja constantemente revisitado até que consigamos nos acostumar com os mapas e os lugares certos, é realmente um "rito de passagem" zerar esse jogo. hahahahaha

É impossível não falar também da trilha sonora que é muito nostalgica, tanto a trilha sonora desse primeiro Turok quanto a trilha sonora do Turok 2 são muito boas, lembro de fazer o dever de casa depois da aula ouvindo. hahahahaha
O interessante dessa versão remasterizada é que os desenvolvedores acrescentaram algumas coisas novas na estrutura dos mapas o que faz com que o jogo seja uma experiência diferente, mesmo para aqueles que já o jogaram anteriormente.

O único problema é o preço, acredito que para uma remasterização de um jogo tão antigo o preço é alto demais, melhor comprar em uma promoção, além do mais são poucas as diferenças gráficas desse para o original.

29043746.review:
I was never able to beat this game without cheats as a kid--in fact I had to use them every time I played it and as a result NTHGTHDGDCRTDTRK is burned into my memory. Buying this remaster has allowed me to remedy that and fill the void of inadequacy that has lingered for so many years. 

Though 20 bucks is a bit steep for an N64 launch title and I doubt anyone who didn't play this and isn't in it for the nostalgia would be interested. But as far as remastered ports go, this is done right.

29040017.review:
Je n'ai jamais joué au jeu orignal. Est-ce que j'ai manqué quelque chose? Et bien d'après cette mouture, oui et non. Je ne sais pas, à vrai dire, s'il me faudrait conseiller ou non ce jeu, mais considérant que je l'ai eu en promotion à 5 boules, disons que ça en valait la peine. A 20 boules, peut-être moins. 

Qu'est-ce qui fait que Turok est cool?

- Il y a des dinosaures. 
- C'est fluide et frénétique. Les nostalgiques des Doom-like apprécieront. 
- Pour l'époque, les graphismes sont potables. Je ne peux pas vraiment juger du travail de remastérisation, par contre, ne pouvant pas comparer au jeu original. 
- La durée de vie est correcte, considérant la difficulté et la rejouabilité. 

Qu'est ce qui fait que Turok est ... pas cool? 

- Les ennemis qui apparaissent totalement randomly, sans raison, comme ça. Ce n'est pas frustrant, ça n'a juste aucune logique et vous fait user vos munitions (et votre patience) pour rien.
- Le fait que les ennemis humains et dinosaures ne se battent pas entre eux, en tout cas pas dans mon jeu. Crédibilité, zéro.
- Les sauts que doivent parfois faire votre personnage d'une plateforme à l'autre sont totalement ridicules, irréalistes, abominables, et manqueront sans doute de vous donner une crise d'hystérie (ou un infarctus, au choix). On peut comprendre la volonté de proposer du challenge, mais bon ... Il faut y jouer pour y croire. 
- Le fait que certains ennemis vous touchent même si vous n'êtes pas dans leur champ de vision (voire même derrière eux). Ce sont sûrement des magiciens, ou des demi-dieux.
- Les bugs. Par exemple cette porte en bois totalement inaccessible dans le niveau 3 (Ancient city) à moins de passer par une manoeuvre qui n'aurait normalement pas été nécessaire. 
- Où est l'histoire? 

Concrètement, cela reste fun à jouer, mais le potentiel est entaché par ces petits détails. En dessous de 10€, je conseille. A 20€, à moins d'être déjà fan de la série/du jeu original ou d'être riche, bof. A vous de voir.

It's a fun game, and if you use the texture packs in the Workshop it looks really good, for a game that's almost 20 years old.

Downsides are: 
big maps that can be tricky to navigate by memory alone, I suggest using the ingame map to help navigate.
Enemies that constantly respawn and eat up your ammo for no reason while exploring.
Save system that means saves are about 30 minutes apart from each other, if you don't die, so be prepared to play without interruption.

I purchased Turok hoping to relive some of those fond N64 memories. And boy does that opening level deliver them. The music. The sound effects. Hearing an enemy soldier scream after blasting him.  Collecting those little golden triangles! Turok is fast.

  Then you get a little further and start disliking the level design. Then you notice that when dead enemies disappear from the playing field, fresh enemies respawn to replace them. Then you notice there's no aiming involved. Just point in the general direction and pull the trigger. 

 Then you realize that Turok really isn't that good of a game. In fact it never was. You could've bought something else with that money. Something better. You click refund and move on. Let someone else collect those triangles. I've got better games to play.

28991595.review:
[h1]Turok (2015) is the essential way to experience the classic N64 FPS. Much like Doom 64 EX (which this same person created), it is a hybrid of a PC gaming engine with N64 assets to make it compatible with modern systems, resolutions and Keybindings. If you can stand the first person platforming, respawning enemies along with limited ammo (on hard mode), potentially annoying backtracking, and N64 Era textures, you'll find an entertaining classic with fun guns.[/h1]

Turok: Dinosaur Hunter on the Nintendo 64 was one of those many games in my childhood that I played and remembered fondly, but never finished. The world design, sound design, and weapons stuck with me. Trying to play it now can be a little cumbersome, so playing it with modern controls and resolutions make it alot easier to play. You can actually find the abandonware of the PC edition - but it is probably missing music and doesn't support modern resolutions and I think you can't rebind keys - also it costs $50 Amazon.  I'm not 100% sure on the development of the game, but it is some sort of hybrid of the N64, a PC engine and maybe the PC version. There are improved graphics (anti-aliasing, lighting), depth of field options (which reduces the distance fog for you AND enmies), and even a recently added Level editor and Workshop/Mod support - I recommend the iddqd_textures (HD Textures)

The game is largely the same as the N64 version, though there are some minor level detail edits/editons that I don't remember from the N64 classic and didn't see in the PC version - so extreme purists might be turned off, but I don't think any "level flow/pathing" has changed. One of the updates mentions the game uses the N64 sounds which were apparently better than the PC version - which is welcome because I loved some of the classic soundtrack (especially Lv 1, Underwater, and Cave themes) and Turok 1 has some of the best death grunts in FPS history. I didn't realize until playing far into this game how prevalent first person platforming is, which will turn some gamers of. Also, some enemies have hitscan weapons - it doesn't make sense how a blowdart can hit me from behind the shooter or the pulse rifle shots hit me near instantly while mine travel a bit slower. You can exploit the AI the bit and most humanoid enemies can be killed in 1-3 knife hits.

I recommend Turok. It comes from a passionate developer that makes blog posts lamenting over minor issues many gamers wouldn't notice.  The $20 tag is high for an old game, but it has at least that amount of work put in to make it happen. At least wishlist it and wait for a sale if you liked the game or have a fondness for classic FPS games.

28991118.review:
J'avoue que je me suis permis un petit delire régressif sur le coup. Je n'avais jamais joué à Turok à la grande époque de la 64, évidemment le nom revenait souvent au hasard des magazines dans le temps, quand j'ai vu ce portage PC à prix cassé la nostalgie l'a emporté..
Que dire de plus , on dégomme du dinosaure et autres joyeux soldats et indigènes au gré des niveaux, on saute sur tout un tas de plate-formes (mon dieu qu'il y a beaucoup de plate-formes ! Ils étaient payés à la pièce ou quoi ?). Et bien sûr on ramasse les différentes clés pour débloquer les niveaux du hub central (une valeur sûre des game design jadis ces hubs).
C'est gore et ça sent fort des aisselles. Ca a excessivement vieilli  mais ça reste assez fun , il faut passer outre les graphismes (même si Night Dive a bien bossé pour lisser le tout), les géométries sont simples et naviguer dans les niveaux n'est pas toujours simple.
Je finis sur une recommandation , en mode nostalgie mal placée.

28989978.review:
Ah, Turok. One of my favourite games from my childhood. Grew up mostly playing this one and Evolution, but man oh man is it a great series. This game in particular is probably one of the best and this remake does it even more justice.

Pros 
- Amazing, powerful, hilariously unrealistic weapons. From the Bow to the Chronoscepter, they're all useful in all stages of the game and incredibly fun to use (my personal favorite being the Grenade Launcher).

- Fun sense of exploration. All of the levels have different secrets to be found, many are in very unsuspecting spots. They are also fairly complex and not so straight-forward.

- Good selection of graphical, audio, video, and gameplay options. I'm so thankful to be able to play with  110 FOV.

- Very Quake-like. Secrets, the weapons, etc. 

- Level Editor! The devs released this pretty recently to open up the community to making their own levels and the like. I've been having a bit of trouble with playing some custom levels, but its not a huge deal. 

Cons
- Lack of story. Not really a major con, as it doesn't really affect the gameplay. You gotta read the comics to get a basis of the game and understand why you're a Native American man running and gunning other men, dinosaurs, dinosaurs WITH GUNS, aliens, robots, etc.

- A LOT OF JUMPING PUZZLES AND PLATFORMING. This isn't something that can really be changed, but it is what it is. They're just a little frustrating on some levels. 

Verdict: 9/10

This is a fantastic game and definitely worth the price.  I'm really looking forward to the remake of Turok 2: Seeds of Evil!

Positive:

28963330.review:
I’ve had the fortune of being alive during most of the major changes and improvements to computers and gaming in general.  I was more of a Nintendo fan back then so the N64 was my main console over the PS1 granted I was till a PC kid but once the N64 games started pumping out games like Goldeneye 64 and Turok I mainly played them for quite some time.  While the N64’s hardware was lacking in a few ways I still loved the console even if by today’s standards looking back it was horribly antiquated compared to disk based console systems.  

Turok was a good game back then, I don’t remember a lot about it but I do recall it running moderately well compared to higher fidelity games like Perfect Dark 64 (even with the extra ram).  It may have been even one of my first semi open world/exploration kind of games that I ever got into but I’m not sure, still though the different worlds/levels and weapons always added some refreshing gameplay from time to time.

This remake of the original PC port is every way better then the 64 version by far, now that it’s on PC you can now mod the game to have say user made higher def textures and now the developer Nightdive studios has added a level editor, something that the original N64 version did not have.  The game itself is everything that I remember it from my younger days yet runs at least 10 times better as far as performance which should go without saying given how powerful PCs are today compared to back then.  If you had fond memories of this game back then or even recently if you are a retro gamer then you will get those same feelings.  

Turok is an early platformer and because of this you will probably die to falls quite a bit or have to redo sections because you fell off or missed a jump.  That is one thing that at times frustrated me because it is quite prevalent in many levels and while the extra performance boost for this port is helpful so that there is little to no input lag you will still probably die or fall many times.

I’m glad that Nightdive is continuing support for the game, as they just recently released the map editor and now the Steam version has Workshop support for user created levels.  I eagerly await Turok 2 if this is the type of quality that I should expect from this developer, and considering they have done other games like a remastering of System Shock 1 and 2 which players seem to like quite a bit.

If you are into retro play or you were alive and playing on an N64 platform you will enjoy this for sure.  Though while the price is a bit steep given how old the game really is, I’d say it’s mostly worth it but I’d still get Turok on sale unless $20 is not that big of a deal for you.

28856490.review:
This remaster is superb, breathing life into the classic FPS. Reinvigorating the sprawling levels and less-than-intricate hidden areas. 
The gameplay remains identical, focusing on a combination of oldschool FPS and platforming puzzles, of which Turok strikes a near perfect balance and offering players comfortable with their jumping prowess certain (albeit rare) unique oppertunities to shortcut certain levels or reach secret areas with increased ease.  
The level design isn't anything special, usually relying on players overthinking to hide treasures essentially in plain sight. However, each level feels unique, enjoyable, and the vast majority of the secret areas feel rewarding to locate. 
All in all, great game and definitely worth picking up if it's on sale.

28849484.review:
Vorwort: Ich habe Turok schon damals auf dem N64 gespielt und sehe das Spiel also vielleicht durch die rosarote Retrobrille.  


1. Story
In Turok spielt man den titelgebenden Ureinwohner Turok. Seine Welt wird von einem Bösen Wesen namens Campaigner bedroht und so macht man sich auf, dass Böse zu besiegen. Wie bei vielen Shootern ist die Story auch hier eher Nebensache. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=824179210

2. Gameplay
Hier bekommt man typische Shooterkost, der man aber anmerkt, dass das Spiel aus einer ganz anderen Zeit kommt. (Release für das N64 war 1997). Das Gameplay ist sehr schnell und die Level teilweise extrem verwinkelt. Ganz anders als bei heutigen Shootern. Und was macht riesig Spaß, wie zu Zeiten von Quake und Unreal durch die Level zu jagen und reflexartig die Gegner abzuknallen. 

3. Steuerung
Ich spiel das Spiel mit M+T wie es sich bei einem Shooter gehört (Wie ich es damals auf dem N64 mit Pad spielen konnte ist mit ein Rätsel) Auch hier ist alles sehr klassisch. Laufen, schießen und springen. Mehr braucht man nicht. Kein Nachladen, keine Deckung suchen.


4. Grafik/Technik/Musik
Die Grafik ist natürlich völlig veraltet war damals aber super. Bei diesem HD Remaster wurde auch kam etwas daran geändert. Es läuft auf aktueller Hardware und in den entsprechenden Auflösungen. Dazu ein paar Kleinigkeiten wie z.B. Godrays und eine schönere Wassertextur. 
Der Soundtrack ist passend und sehr treibend. Dazu hört man immer wieder einen Dino brüllen. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=824179168

5. Add-On: 
Gibt es nicht. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=826445015

6. Multiplayer: 
Gibt es nicht.

7. Achievments: 
Ich habe 7 von 8 geschafft (88% ) bei einmaligem Durchspielen.  

8. In-Home Streaming / Steam Link
Nicht getestet.

9. Pro und Contra 

Pro:
- Wunderbares Retro Shootergameplay
- Toller und treibender Sound. 
- Gute Steuerung
- Schöne und komplexe Level mit verschiedenen Themen. 
- Viele Waffen die man auch alle dabei hat.
- Faire Bosskämpfe.
-	Freies Speichern
-	Unverbrauchtes Setting

Contra:
- Grafik veraltet. 
-	Recht kurze Spielzeit.
-	Teilweise zu komplexes Level Design so dass man trotz Karte eine bisschen herumirrt. 


10. Fazit
Als Fan der ersten Stunde hat es riesig Spaß gemacht, das Spiel nochmal durchzuspielen. Vor allem mit HD Grafik und mit M+T. Jüngeren Spielergenerationen würde ich aber von dem Game abraten. Es ist grafisch zu alt und auch sonst nicht mit aktuellen Shootern zu vergleichen (evtl. noch mit dem neuen Doom). Fans der alten Turok Spiele kann ich dieses Remaster aber ans Herz legen. Ich hatte sehr viel Spaß damit, zumal man doch einiges Vergessen hat. Im Sale war das Spiel für 5 Euro zu bekommen. Der Release Preis war mit 20 € für meine Begriffe zu hoch angesetzt. Der Entwickler hat auch schon angekündigt, dass Turok 2 ebenfalls kommen wird. Ich freu mich drauf, zumal ich den zweiten Teil nur mal angespielt habe. 

Vergleichbare Spiele: 
Alte und schnelle Shooter der alten Schule wie Doom, Quake, Unreal usw. 

Fragen und Anregungen oder Kritik immer gerne in die Kommentare posten :-) 

PC: 
Intel i5 2500K @ 4Ghz
16 GB Ram
nVidia GF 970 mit 376.09
Win 10 Pro 64 Bit

28797122.review:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spiel: 

Ein Klassischer Ego-Shooter aus den 90ern ohne viel Schnick-Schnack neu aufgelegt.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Einzelspieler:

Man spielt einen Indianer der aus irgendeinem Grund alles tötet was so rumläuft. Keine Ahnung warum aber eine Story gibt es nicht, aufjedenfall ist von Menschen, Dinos, Käfern, Echsen und Robotern alles dabei. Es gibt ausserdem 4 verschiedene Schwierigkeitsgrade die man einfach ändern kann nach Belieben.

Man kämpft sich von Level zu Level sucht Schlüssel, Chronozepter-Teile (für die stärkste Waffe im Spiel) und Secrets. Die Level sind alle sehr weitläufig aufgebaut und haben immer verschiedene Thematiken, im Spielverlauf bekommt man allerhand Waffen die alle ihren eigenen Charme haben und auch für verschiedene Gegnerarten Speziell sind. Was das Spiel vielleicht etwas Schwieriger macht ist das man nur an Speicherpunken Speichern kann und der Rest des Levels mit Checkpoints ausgestattet ist.

Es ist auch keine 1:1 Umsetzung von der PC oder N64 Version die man gut auf YouTube vergleichen kann.

Die Änderungen sind:
-	Es gibt ein paar neue Schlüsselstandorte
-	Die Grafik ist besser als bei der N64 oder alten PC Version
-	Die Auflösung kann sehr hoch gestellt werden und hat Widescreen
-	Die Musik ist die von der PC Version und nicht von der N64
-	Es ist Modbar gemacht worden und hat einen Workshop
-	Uncut im Gegensatz zur Deutschen Version

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grafik:

Die Grafik aufjedenfall besser als die von der alten PC Version und vom Nintendo 64. Das Game sieht aufjedenfall nicht schlecht aus, kann aber auch nicht mit 3 Textur Mods aufgehübscht werden.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Musik:

Die Musik ist auch immer sehr passend zu jedem Level, passt immer genau zum Level.
(alternativ kann man auch den Nintendo 64 Soundtrack manuell einfügen der auch sehr gut ist. http://steamcommunity.com/app/405820/discussions/1/494632768635046610/)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Steuerung:

Die Steuerung einfach Top, sehr genau und schön schnell. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pro/Contra:

+ gutes Gameplay
+ gute Grafik
+ gute Musik
+ gute Steuerung
+ Uncut
+ Modbar mit Workshop
- ein paar Bugs gibt’s leider immer noch
- leider immer noch ein bisschen Nebel
- viel zu teuer

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fazit:

Ich habe damals als Kind Turok auf dem Nintendo 64 gespielt, die Weitsicht war wenig und die Steuerung war schwer, aber diese Version lohnt sich wirklich als Oldschool Shooter Fan. Es hat eigentlich alles was man haben will, es läuft gut und lässt sich wunderbar spielen.  Wem das aber nicht genug ist der kann sich ja dieses Modpack runterladen was es nochmal ein bisschen Schicker aussehen lässt und ein Paar Bugs ausbügelt und neue Sachen einfügt wie z.B. die Handgranate.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=826472182 

Ich habe zum durchspielen circa 8 Stunden gebraucht auf Normal, aber wenn man schon alles kennt wird hier sicherlich schneller durchkommen.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Zusammengefasst: 

Einzelspieler: 9/10
Grafik: 7/10
Musik: 9/10
Steuerung: 10/10
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Spiel: 9/10

28685319.review:
At first I thought this would be - in absolutely best case - a decent remake. Now as I have played my way though half of the game and just completed Level 4 I have to say that buying this game (even only at -75%, sorry Nightdive) was absolutely one of my best buys this year.
This game brings back so much memories and is so fun to play. I thought like "what the hell, 97% positive reviews ... they can not be serious" before, but i pretty much like it too. This is one gold old FPS from "good old times" :)
One thing I was a bit confused about is that Level 1 is at some points DIFFERENT from the Level 1 on N64 (PAL Version). I only can compare it to N64 PAL version, not to the original PC Version.
This might also apply to some other Levels. I guess you originally were NOT able to get the Minigun in Level 2 (a few metres away from the end portal) because you could not destroy the "spikes" with a Tek-Arrow. In Level 3 it seemed like there have been some backpacks added, but some Tek Armors are missing. I played it more than 15 years ago for the last time, so maybe I remember something wrong^^
The games is apparently faster than before and I think this is really good.
Still each level untill now took about 45-60 minutes for me to complete it.
I liked the robots in N64 PAL version more than the humans in this version, because the robots colours were more different from the environment, while I have got sometimes problems to see enemie humans near some walls. Moreover the robots just disappeared when they were dead, while the humans sometimes still keep on moving some seconds and you can not be sure if they are really dead already.

The only pretty bad issue:
Your characters positioning is sometimes very frustrating. Back on N64 I could very good use the character arrow on the minimap and center it on some plattforms at areas requiring lots of jumping. The center of the arrow was the center of your character. NOW the tip of the arrow is the center of the your character. When you look down to where your feets are supposed to be and then go to the edge of a plattform, you will fall down (visually through the plattform) even if you see yourself still standing on the plattform.This feels and plays really different from the original. especially in Level 3 directly before the boss I messed up more jumps than ever before in all complete playthroughs of Turok.
This problem also occurs at some stairs in Level 3. If you a close to a stair and want strafe to the left or right, then you can not move. It feels like if there is a invisible wall.
When you turn around 180°, then you can understand both of these issues, as your view then is completely different from before. Then you can see, that you are leaving the plattform and you can see that you are still next to the stairs.
Something is pretty wrong with it to be honest.
And one more smaller issue... dodging the falling down rocks at some point in Level 2 really is a PAIN. If you dont look at the sky (where you can see them hanging^^) and are REALLY slowly and carefully, then you will get smashed. If you walk straight forward and hear the sound of them falling, they it is already too late and you will die.
Moreover I had wished that you (even though it also was not possible in the original game) can change the ammo of Bow and and Shotgun, so that you can choose on your own whether to use arrow or tek-arrow and regular shotgun ammo or explosive shotgung ammo. I pretty much never use all of my explosive shotgun ammo (dont wanna waste it^^), so I barely ever could collect any regular shotgun ammo.

But still this is really a great old-school FPS, which I absolutely can recommend, but - sorry again Nightdive studios - not for the full price of 20 bucks. I bought it at -75% and if I had knewn before how good and fun it is, i would have bought it before already at -50%.
At max. 10 Bucks you can not do anything wrong buying it, when you are a fan of old FPS games.

EDIT:
Now I have completely finished the game after about 8 hours. More or less 1 hour each level, but Level 8 took longer. I could not remember how big it is^^
Just to add: In one Level I had some technical problems which only could be fixed by restarting the game. I am not really sure if they really had an influence on the gameplay or if they just were some graphical bugs.

Terrible graphics, no physics, unrealistic weapons, no iron sights, and I didn't even play the original... why on Earth would I recommend this game?

I always wanted to play Turok when it first came out, but never had an N64. I was excited to see it make it's way to Steam, but didn't buy it until it was 75% off. I didn't really plan on playing it much, just wanted to see what I missed as a teen. Now I'm a little addicted to the game! Of the N64 games I did play, this one is pretty revolutionary! It has a lot of neat stuff like swimming and climbing that I didn't know you could do in an N64 FPS.

But what really pulls me into the game is how fluid and fast paced it is. It reminds me of a bygone era of FPS's that I used to love. No hiding, no sneaking, no reloading. Just run and gun!

28630618.review:
​[h1]ANÁLISIS DE "TUROK: DINOSAUR HUNTER":​[/h1]


Nostalgia. Es la primera palabra que se me viene a la cabeza al hablar de Turok: Dinosaur Hunter. No se trata solamente del mismo juego que maravilló al mundo tanto en Nintendo 64 como en PC hayá por el 97, sino que estamos ante una edición mejorada con bastante trabajo detrás para mejorar la experiencia que nos ofrecía Turok, que ya en su época era sobresaliente.  

Si estás leyendo esto seguramente sea porque como yo, jugaste a Turok en su día en PC o N64, donde destacó de sobremanera por unos gráficos espectaculares para su época, una jugabilidad endiabladamente frenética y niveles gigantescos llenos de secretos por descubrir, puzzles, trampas, etc. acompañados de un arsenal enorme y variado y una gran cantidad de enemigos entre los que se encuentran los famosos dinosaurios, uno de los principales atractivos del juego. 

Gracias a todo esto y más, el primero de la saga está considerado como uno de los mejores shooters que existieron por aquel entonces y que aún a día de hoy se sigue recordando, aunque la mayoría de los demás juegos que continuaron la saga no estuvieran a la altura (salvo Turok 2, que fue genial y que también viene camino de Steam remasterizado de la mano de Nightdive Studios). 

¿Qué tiene este Turok que hace que sea la mejor versión disponible? pues muy fácil: aparte de añadir total compatibilidad con sistemas operativos y equipos actuales, podemos jugar a altas resoluciones, se han mejorado texturas, distancia de representación, efectos de luz, algunas modificaciones en los niveles (desde hace unos días incluye editor), reflejos en el agua, logros y un control totalmente remodelado, adaptándose al ratón + teclado a la perfección y añadiendo total compatibilidad con mando. 

Todo lo que un remaster debe tener: respetando fielmente el título original pero puliendo pequeños detalles y añadiendo mejoras para que la experiencia sea lo mejor posible teniendo en cuenta la antigüedad del juego.

Os dejo mi lista de pros y contras (muchas cosas se valoran en función de la época en la que salió el juego): 

​[h1]PROS:​[/h1]

- Si fuiste fan de Turok en su época, ES UNA COMPRA OBLIGADA

- Remaster muy currado: respeta fielmente al título original pero incluye muchas mejoras que lo hacen muy disfrutable a pesar de la antigüedad

- La mejora del control es impresionante, muy recomendable usar ratón y teclado. También da la opción de jugar con mando

- Está traducido al español

- Funciona perfectamente en sistemas operativos y equipos actuales 

- Jugabilidad frenética, hará las delicias de todo amante de la vieja escuela de los shooters clásicos

- Niveles enormes y llenos de secretos, puzzles y trampas

- Muy configurable: se puede ajustar absolutamente todo para hacer la experiencia más o menos fiel al original o adaptarlo más a los estándares actuales de jugabilidad 

- Enoooorme variedad de armas y munición: cuchillo, pistola, arco, escopetas, rifles, lanza-misiles, lanza-rayos, lanzagranadas, armas alienígenas y mucho más

- Las animaciones están muy logradas para la época, especialmente los movimientos de los dinosaurios

- Algunos temas de la banda sonora son muy buenos, tan frenéticos como el ritmo del juego

- Podemos elegir los niveles según vayamos consiguiendo las llaves, no hay que seguir un orden

- El gore: el realismo de la sangre, ver cómo se desangran los enemigos y cómo se retuercen de dolor antes de morir. Fue una auténtica pasada para su época

- La IA de los enemigos para la época está bastante bien

- El efecto de los rayos de sol es impresionante, mejor que el de muchos juegos actuales

- Si ya de por sí el agua de Turok era una pasada en su época, ahora le han añadido el efecto del reflejo que queda espectacular

- Gran variedad de enemigos

- Se pueden volver a visitar los niveles para seguir buscando llaves y objetos ocultos

- El T-Rex del final es espectacular

- Poder volver a escuchar la frase de "I am Turok!"

- Tiene sistema de guardado de la partida en la nube Steam Cloud 

- Tiene logros Steam

- Por fin lo han rebajado al 75%, quedando a un precio de 4,99€ (oferta temporal)


​[h1]CONTRAS:​[/h1]

- A veces tiene algún que otro bajón de frames, nada importante ni que perjudique la jugabilidad, pero que se nota por haber hecho modificaciones en un motor tan antiguo, exprimido al máximo para mejorar el aspecto visual 

- La música puede llegar a hacerse un poco repetitiva en algunos niveles

- No tiene cromos Steam

- Podrían haber añadido más logros

- Se echan en falta más dinosaurios

- Es fácil perderse por algunos niveles que tienen un diseño más repetitivo

- Salió a un precio algo elevado para tratarse de un juego tan antiguo, en las ofertas de Steam he podido conseguirlo a 4,99€ que sí me parece un precio acorde


​[h1]CONCLUSIÓN:​[/h1] 

Si jugaste a Turok: Dinosaur Hunter en su día y quieres recordar viejos tiempos y disfrutar de este juegazo de la mejor forma posible, cómpralo sin dudarlo. También lo recomendaría si te lo perdiste en su día y quieres jugar uno de los mejores shooters de todos los tiempos, un juego que fue de vital importancia en el género tal y como lo conocemos hoy día. Cómpralo de oferta a 4,99€ si es posible, ha tardado en bajar pero al final ha llegado y ahora SÍ es una compra obligada.


Si mi análisis te ha servido de ayuda o te ha gustado, agradecería que dejaras tu valoración positiva para que pueda leerlo más gente. No dudéis en escribir abajo si tenéis cualquier tipo de duda. ¡Un saludo y gracias por leerme!

28432560.review:
[h1] A oldschoolshooter with passion and character.	[/h1]

Back in the mid 90's those graphics and sounds were a milestone in videogaming history.
I remember me and many classmates with an N64 bought it and we loved  to tell gameplay stories about it when it was boring at elementary school.
We shared many cheat codes we encountered and loved it to go rampage with this sharp-screaming minigun :)

[u] Ok enough nostagica, lets come to the facts:	[/u]
[list]
    [*] A nice amount of weapons, reaching from a knife to a nuclear fusion-canon. collect one secret part each level, to get the Chronocepter, the most powerfull weapon in game
    [*] Explore 8 Levels in the Lost Land, including jungle, ancient aities, catacombs and cyber. The levels are very long and sometimes like a maze. The only point where i could give the developers a 'lil slap. :)
    [*] Fight against wildhunters, dinosaurs, monsters, aliens and later..... "orbit to fire!"
    [*] 5 bosses are waiting for you!
[/list]

Nightdive Studios did a very good revive on this game. The gameplay is very proper and smooth with keyboard and mouse on modern PC's. They also increased the viewdistance, FPS  and many other improvements. They even terraformed an small area in Level 1, go find your auto :)
Dear Nightdive Studios i tried the gallery cheat for spectating the enemies [spoiler]THBST[/spoiler]  and it wont work. I wish you could fix it.

Do the same good job with Turok 2!

Gran FPS de mundo abierto, puzzles y escondites... rápido como el viento y frenético!!!! A decir verdad, muy superior a muchos FPS de hoy en día. Adoro Call of Duty. Pero Turok Dinosaur Hunter es simplemente.... superior a la mayoría de FPS actuales. Es un mundo abierto en el que tienes que estar constantemente alerta.... plagado de dinosaurios y seres alienígenas antropomórficos, con unos escenarios muy bonitos pese al paso de los años, y un diseño de niveles muy complejo y excepcional.

Recomiendo mucho esta versión: la jugabilidad está mejorada (que al original, le hacía falta), no te encuentras tanto la puta niebla de la versión antigua y han mejorado los gráficos de una manera que.... joder, ¡qué bonitos!

Es una obra maestra. Los 19 euros yo creo que los merece, me lo he pasado en dos días y lo he disfrutado como un niño. Sino, pilladlo de rebajas; ya que si os gustan los FPS -clásicos o modernos- ,Turok: Dinosaur Hunter es simplemente un imprescindible.

28222916.review:
A masterful port of a Nintendo 64 classic that has not aged very well

PROS:
+ Fast-paced, old-school first-person shooter gameplay
+ Creative bestiary, ranging from native warriors to cyborg dinosaurs!
+ Many visual improvements over its N64 counterpart, including increased draw distance
+ Well-optimised engine with full mouse/keyboard support, modern-day options and widescreen resolutions

CONS:
- Dated graphics
- No walk/run roggle
- Respawning enemies
- Repetitive environments
- Jumping puzzles over bottomless pits
- Lackluster higher-tier weapons, such as the Shockwave Weapon and the Alien Weapon

I don't review much, but for this game I had to. If you are reading this, I would highly suggest to stop and just buy it while its on for such a great price. You can't go wrong this classic. I'll give you a quick run down. Also before you continue, just know I never had this for N64 so I'm not raving about it because of nostalgia. 

+PURE FUN, this game really nailed the fun factor.
+Diversity of weapons, and the gunplay is really tight
+Plenty of discovery and exploration while the constant slaughter of dinosaurs, creatures, and random mercs/humanoids alike
+Good soundtrack that fits the theme really well
+Runs super smooth for this PC port, so if you like the n64 version get this without hesitating,
+Healthy challenge, not too hard or easy
+Awesome Boss fights
+One of the best FPS games to date

-Medium Length, and decent replay value. 
-$19.99 may be a steep price if you're unsure if you would like it or not, so only play full price if you know you'll enjoy it. 

TL;DR : Fantastic shooter, great levels, good for old and newer fans, so don't be intimidated by it.

The dinosaur hunter Turok has returned in this remake of the original game. It is just as nostalgic as it should be for those who played it back on the N64 and original PC versions but still welcoming to beginners. 27733622.review:
Have you ever looked back fondly at an FPS, gone b ack to it and been like "holy crap, how did i play like this!?" due to fps, or controls, or something. Turok was certainly one of those games on the n64. A unique blend of speedy fps action, item collection, and open level design marred horribly by TERRIBLE fps on its original console.

26435823.review:
Turok Dinosaur Hunter: Der erste Teil der Turok-Saga und eines besten Spiele die es zu seiner Zeit auf PC und N64 gab. Ich habe die ersten 3 Level und den ersten Boss geschafft und muss sagen, dass ich mich wieder wie der kleine Junge gefühlt habe, der ich bei Release der ursprünglichen Version in 1997 gewesen bin. Das Spiel wurde ordentlich aufgehübscht, soweit es bei der alten Engine möglich ist, läuft auf meinem PC (Win8.1 64-bit) wie eine 1 und die Steuerung geht butterweich und genau von der Hand, wie es sich für eine Ego-Shooter-Steuerung gehört. Das Gefühl, wenn man nach so langer Zeit wieder mit Messer, Pfeil und Bogen und diversen anderen Schießeisen gegen Dinosaurier und Söldner kämpft und einen langen Unterwassertunnel entlang schwimmt, um geheime Wege und andere Geheimnisse zu finden, ist einfach unbeschreiblich. Und um dem Lobgesang noch die Krone aufzusetzen: Deutsch und Uncut. 

Was für heutige Gamer und Fans von Ego-Shootern etwas ungewohnt sein dürfte, ist die Suche nach Schlüsseln um die weiteren Level zu öffnen und die Suche nach den Teilen einer Superwaffe, die im gesamten Spiel verstreut sind. Falls jemand modernste HD Grafik gewohnt ist, könnte dieser ein wenig enttäuscht sein. Aber da die Orginalfassung von 1997 ist, sieht das Ganze (trotz des Alters der Engine) odentlich aus. Ich hab es mir für 19,99 gekauft und werde es auch behalten, muss aber sagen, dass 14,99€ ein absolut ausreichender Preis gewesen wären.

So müssen alte Spiele remastered werden. Bitte bringt Turok 2 und 3 auch in aufgehübschter Fassung raus. Für alle, die sich nach "den alten Zeiten" sehnen, Turok-Fans der ersten Stunde und Shooter-Fans ist dieses Spiel ein absoluter Pflichtkauf.

26321595.review:
[h1]Travel back in time...[/h1]

No, not to when dinosaurs existed. To 1997! A time when 3D graphics had firmly supplanted 2D on consoles, and analog control was new. A time when reflection mapping and particle effects meant a game was realistic, and we considered these derp faces highly detailed.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=789409826

A time when platforming meant insanely challenging precision hopping 1,000 feet in the air between what one magazine article of the era lamented as "floating rocks the size of dinner plates." All with slippery, floaty controls compared to what you're likely used to today, and a draw distance we all didn't know better than to think was just "ambient fog" that added atmosphere to our games.

An era where grey, green, and lava red were considered a stunningly vibrant array of colors.

[h1]Make dinosaurs extinct again[/h1]

This game... ohhh, this game! When I purchased an N64 back in the 90s, I got four games with it. Doom 64 (still my favorite classic style Doom ever,) Mario 64, Star Wars Shadows of the Empire (someone please remaster it with modern controller support and upscale like this game, please!) ... and Turok: Dinosaur Hunter.

By today's standards, this is a brief, ridiculously challenging on any difficulty above easy from the second or third level on, very ugly, less than ideally controllable (although it feels fine with mouse and keyboard) first person shooter. But in 1997, it felt revolutionary. With a speed and polish something akin to the original Quake, graphics which at the time were gorgeously slick, the appeal of fighting dinosaurs and soldiers in jungles, and plenty of secrets, it was a big hit and a staple on the system.

This is a fairly no frills port, but adds modern controller support, FOV settings (I recommend the lowest one for something akin to the original game's FOV, but crank it up for that high speed feeling fisheye effect if you want it,) vibrancy settings (with Reshade - use version 3 and OpenGL incidentally - and vibrancy turned on but all the way down, the game really pops and looks like the original but with much higher contrast,) FXAA, bloom, *massively increased draw distance*and other bells and whistles. There is no retexture, but existing textures natively scale all the way to 4K resolutions. So everything looks sharp, if dated.

There are eight levels, and one hub stage. The goal of the levels is to find all the keys which unlock subsequent stages (so if you miss any, you'll need to replay them a bit.) Saves work via manual save points, and a checkpoint system only restores you after death during your current session. Loading always takes you to your last manual save point. Old school.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=788498785

The game is much more challenging than I remember. Some of that is due to revamped AI toughness, but mainly it's just that this is a pretty challenging game, especially the platforming sections. I'm much better at it now than I was in the 90s, thankfully. But expect a tough time due to the save system. 

Using a controller, the game works fine (native dual analog control just like you'd expect,) but even after tweaking the sensitivity and turn acceleration settings for more than an hour, I couldn't ever get it to feel quite as precise as modern games do. The acceleration curves are very dated. Mouse and keyboard feel great, however. That said, I did adapt and play with my 360 controller. I wanted to relive the console experience, just with twin analog. 

Level variety is decent. Jungles, treetop villages, lost ruins, volcanic plains, and mechanical bases. Enemies are pretty epic in my opinion. Dinosaurs, soldiers, soldiers riding dinosaurs, dinosaurs modified with weapons, and later on, some fairly intimidating mechs. And this Suburban Commando era Hulk Hogan looking boss that I completely forgot about until replaying the game after 20 years.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=788498946

Weapon variety is nice. Exploding arrows, a variety of guns, advanced energy weapons... all the things you'd expect. This game and its sequel always stuck out in my mind as the point where modern, animated weapons, and crazy alien tech with blue glowy energy started showing up in first person shooters. They still look pretty good, and as mentioned, have some pleasing particle effects. Honestly at times while replaying this, I was reminded of the Halo games' arsenals. Which may give you some idea of how modern it felt for 1997.

[h1]Who should buy it?[/h1]

Anyone cool with old school games in the vein of Quake, but with a more outdoor vibe. Anyone who doesn't mind old school save systems, and challenging platforming.

[h1]Who should steer clear?[/h1]

Anyone who doesn't want tough platforming sections, limited lives, manual save points, and dated visuals. Anyone who was hoping for a true HD retexture.

26175740.review:
Turok: Dinosaur Hunter is an FPS that originally appeared on Nintendo 64 in 1997 and later ported to the PC, unbeknownst to some. The Turok series has always been a strange one: Largely popular on the N64 platform it was best known for, but it had absolutely nothing on PC shooter competition even in the year it came out. Its sequels would take radical turns in gameplay style and features, often with mixed results, with Turok 2: Seeds of Evil typically being regarded as the last great Turok game, at least the last one most similar to its predecessor. A lousy reboot in 2008 simply called Turok all but killed off the semi-popular franchise, at least until last year when Night Dive Studios resurrected the first title and gave it a bit of a facelift (remaster, not remake) bringing the N64 classic to a wider audience. I never owned thus never played it on the N64 but I did acquire the PC version many years ago and enjoyed it quite a lot despite its shortcomings.

Turok was originally a comic book, Turok: Son of Stone in the 60's, a relatively innocent series of books about two Native American brothers who went on adventures in a desolate valley populated with dinosaurs. In the early 90's Valiant Comics brought back a revamped series called Turok: Dinosaur Hunter and the setting was vastly altered: the valley is now 'The Lost Lands', a place where time moves in a self-contained loop. With dinosaurs, aliens, demons and future tech in a bizarre unison. The villain is an entity known as Mothergod who uses the Lost Land as a base of operations and outfits dinosaurs with intelligence-boosting implants turning them into 'bionisaurs'. From there on there's things like a post-apocalyptic future Earth, various Lovecraftian abominations and high-tech future warriors. Yeah, the 90's were here. There's many elements in this iteration that would show up in the games. Later on another series was published by Acclaim Comics in 1998 as a tie-in for Turok 1 and 2.

Turok is not a character's name but a title meaning 'Son of Stone'. For many generations the mantle of Turok has been bestowed upon those who saw the protection of the barrier as their sacred duty, the barrier between this world and the others. The axis of all being the Lost Lands. Turok travels between alternate dimensions stopping those who would try to conquer the Lost Lands and thus all of the multiverse with it. In this game you are Tal'Set, a time-travelling Saquin warrior tasked with stopping The Campaigner, an evil warlord who controls a vast army of creatures in addition to his own troops, seeking pieces of the Chronoscepter in the Lost Lands. This ancient artifact, once assembled contains the power to rule the known universe.

Turok's gameplay is standard for the era but closest I can compare it to would be the first Quake. Movement speed and jumping height are excellent and grant you a lot of mobility which allows you to easily sidestep and jump over enemy attacks. And jumping you will be doing a lot of, for even the most rudimentary skill it is absolutely mandatory to master if you're going to finish the game. Platforming is commonplace but not hard to pull off and is very responsive. Among this there's an assortment of keys you obtain in each level which are used to unlock the next, and a piece of the Chronoscepter in each level as well. The majority of the game takes place in outdoor environments with the occasional indoor section. Exploration is key as there's all kinds of stuff hidden around. Interactivity is decent with being able to scale certain walls, swimming, collapsing trees with explosive weapons and hunting deer and warthogs for extra health (tip: use regular shotgun shells for best results). There's no use function so activating things requires a simple approach or stepping on pressure plates. There's only eight levels but they're pretty large and take anywhere from 45 minutes to a little over an hour to finish.

The bestiary is surprisingly varied, well animated and different from one another. It's a bit ironic that the game's subtitle is Dinosaur Hunter since 6 of the 8 levels contain mainly humanoid enemy types like poachers, evil natives and the Campaigner's own troops. But there's a host of other lifeforms like cave dwelling leapers, giant beetles, the ape-like Purr-Linn, and of course dinosaurs, mainly biomechanical velociraptors and dimetrodons. The enemies get more bizarre the further you go, with aliens, demons and robots near the end and of course a few bosses sprinkled along the way. Death animations are also pretty violent, but nowhere near as gory as the sequel, considering this was on the N64 but by that time Nintendo had backed off with its censorship. People grab their throats with blood jetting out of their neck and raptors produce a crimson volcano from their maw more often than not, but it's pretty tame by today's standards.

The weapons were another highlight from this time period as most shooters had little more than 10 or so but Turok boosts a whoppin' 14 in all. From a lowly knife and Tek Bow to high-tech death dealing in the form of the atomic energy Fusion Cannon to the Chronoscepter itself. And all manner of shotguns, miniguns, grenade and rocket launchers, and alien technology in between. They're all great fun to use and are one of the main selling points of the game. The iconic Cerebral Bore from Turok 2 isn't in this one but what's here already is more than sufficient to get the job done.

Visuals are obviously aged with early 3D models and low res textures but they're still competent like Quake's IMO and leave little guesswork as to what the hell you're looking at. As stated earlier everything's animated well and the addition of updated graphics options in this remaster do make things look a bit nicer. Originally the draw distance for the fog was abysmal due to console restrictions, the FOV was insanely low and the frame rate for the original PC version was capped at something odd like 42. Now the draw distance allows you to see more things (and some things you probably weren't meant to see), the FOV isn't retarded and the frame rate's a silky 60 easily making this the superior version of the game. Audio's low quality as they come straight from the source but they're not too ear-grating. The music's not bad though and mostly consists of fitting tribal beats, dreary ambient pieces and a sinister industrial style on the final level. The levels are mostly set in a jungle or ancient temple but throw some curve balls later on. Night Dive greatly reduced frustration in exploring these by doing some very minor streamlining, removing redundant hallways or reworking a section to flow better, and the placement of certain keys and some extra save zones on the tougher maps.

Criticisms include the low difficulty in combat as most enemies aren't that challenging to fight and are easily exploited due to their animation, but hitscanners can be annoying and the pulse rifle wielding Campaigner sergeants are extremely aggressive and require a lot of jumping around while laying into them to not get hit. Hard difficulty isn't that much harder and just makes everyone bullet spongy and removes pickups from dead enemies, effectively screwing you out of the Mortal Wound pickup (permanently raises base health) if killing with the knife or regular arrows. Limited save areas as a result of consoles and the amount of platforming can be tedious, and the Chronoscepter piece on level 7 is very out of the way (useful hint: not all lava hurts you). Lastly if you can score hits with the Chronoscepter on the Campaigner it massively cheeses him.

Overall, Turok is a very 90's FPS in its design but that's largely what makes it so unique and fun to play and I highly recommend it to fans of the genre. Happy hunting.

4.0/5

This is worth all of it's price and more. For just 20 bucks you get a solid game while contemporary shooters are 3-4 times the price (+extras), but they don't offer anything. This game however is a classic and even has some improvements compared to the present trends of making bad changes and expecting them to be OK after calling that process "evolving". Anyway, you still maintain all the qualities of the original game, but you get some improvements...

*HD compatibility
*60/75 FPS (didn't test whether more is possible)
*Computer input devices play much better than an N64 controller
*Fluent inputs, no odd delays like in some console games or ports
*Crosshair can be turned on
*Bobbing can be reduced in options menu
*Minor visual improvements on top of this
*Based on original version, not the German Commi Censorship version

Games like this should be developed again instead of garbage like these new shooters with autohealing, minimal arsenal, extremely poor maps, contemporary graphics without ability to turn them low etc... Make more games like Dinosaur Hunter and Seeds of Evil!

25806383.review: Turok is a solid remaster of the classic N64 title that I never had a chance to thoroughly play back then.  This remaster has a fantastic list of improvements, including options to push back the thick fog that hid the technical limitations of the old hardware, along with a handy FOV toggle.  The game is certainly a relic of its time, with punishing lives and checkpoint systems, not to mention a ridiculous amount of 1st person platforming--a concept that has mostly fallen out of favor in modern shooters.  I still find it to be a solid title, though, with open level designs that demand clever exploration and a bit of light puzzle solving.

25689200.review:
Excellent game and great fun for a quick romp in the jungle. I never played the original (no nostalgia bias) but for me this seemed to evoke the best of old school shooter games. You don't have to think to hard but it's fast and action packed, and it works fantastically well with mouse and keyboard which is where a lot of this type of game fall down on clunkiness.

£15 is a little steep for it considering you can complete in under 10 hours so I would recommend you add it to wishlist and wait for it to come in nice and cheap.

25639599.review: I had joined the Master Race by the time this game was released, so I had no chance to play it in the '90s. Playing it now, I can tell why it was such a big deal back in the day. The maps have massive size, which is impressive for a game that predates Unreal by a year. The graphics are fast and smooth, and the audio (both music and sound effects) is perfect for the game's fast pace. Combat is satisfying, and I especially like how almost every weapon retains its usefulness until the end. PC players used to toxic savescumming might not like the limited save options, but overall it makes for a more challenging experience. There are some tedious platforming sections (your deaths in this game will probably be mostly due to falling), but I can imagine these having been a lot more frustrating with a controller. The maps are centered around a good hub system which may throw you off at first, and while some of the maps could use a bit clearer layout (the Catacombs are a pretty bad experience), overall there's good variety in them and room for exploration. Still, 20€ might be just a little bit too much for such an old game, especially when the campaign is only about five hours long.

25615397.review: A remaster of a 1997 classic, done right. Night Dive Studios have a good record with resurrecting older games and putting them on Steam. Turok is no exception, as it now supports modern resolutions, 60fps, and has better mouse support. The game is just as fun as I remember it, and the nostalgia is fully preserved through the minimal changes they’ve made gameplay/graphics wise. A little bit on the pricey side, but for fans of the series like me, it was worth every penny.

25553524.review:
The Good

-Solid gameplay, with fun level design taking plenty of cues from 3d platformers of the day
-Good variety of unique weapons to use
-Great boss fights
-Looks fantastic, the remaster was very well done, with added effects to boot
-Those death animations never get old
-Great soundtrack


The Bad

-Levels tend to drag on a bit long with checkpoints being really spread out
-Wonky hit detection sometimes when aiming at enemies (Very rare however)
-AI isn't the greatest / Pretty stupid
-FPS platforming can be a pain (minor, for me personally but I know some people dread it)



The Opinion

With everything said and done, I feel Night Dive Studios have done an incredible job bringing a classic first person shooter to a potential new audience, it holds up well for the most part in terms of gameplay all these years later and looks fantastic running in an HD resolution, I feel $20 USD though is a bit steep of a price, I'd say definitely pick this up on sale if you're looking for some nostalgia or looking to experience an early FPS title when the genre was still new and fresh.


You can watch the full video review below, for a more detailed review and the history behind Turok

24490574.review:
This is a really tough game, I liked the action in this game. Though there were some moments further in the game where it questions you "Are the developers on crack when they are making this?" lol.

So far the game is good, it lacks the story in game. All starts with you playing as Turok and you must collect the keys to unlock the levels, which is the max of 8 levels. Theres also a secret weapon through every level. Find it and you can use it, useful on the final battle.

Pros:

Great weapons.
massive killing later in the game.
A game where you look for important items in order to progress.
No glitches or bugs except for one which i'll explain later in the bottom.
You play as a Indian tribe using modern weapons, so why not?

Cons:

Less ammo and health, you have to be very conservative with your health and ammo, you also have lives which can be used for full health when you die. I just wish there can be some mystic water that regenerates health or something but I guess you'll have to play smart in order to beat it.

No autosaves or quick saves, you have to use a golden statue in order to save your game which is throughout the game. It gets pressuring without saving later, but when you do, its a relief. You have to walk at it in order to save your game.

Overall: Its a really good game and I have a blast. Its actually worth a buy.

Glitch/bug: Theres a white flickering light when you start playing and it gets annoying. However, I discovered the solution. Just click this link for instructions as it helped me and I was able to play it perfectly well.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/405820/discussions/0/365172547950979990/

Follow it and you should be able to play.

Tips:

DO NOT KILL ALL ENEMIES! Not sure if it depends on difficulty (I played hardcore) but some enemies respawn but not all. Just dont kill everyone, use your ammo wisely as I said its low. Very scarce. Some enemies like dinosaurs are not necessary to kill, if you seen some just run away. Dont bother knifing if you know how to not take damage and if you are patient. If any monsters that respawn such as dinosaurs are in your way, kill them but get out of that area quickly before they respawn. Which would mean you waste your ammo for nothing and you'll have a hard time finding refills.

A secret weapon will help you in the final boss battle and the last piece of it will always be at the final boss so no worries, always keep your eyes on any suspicious areas. You'll know when you get it from the key menu in the pause menu. Its that lonely symbol from the other symbols (other symbols are keys btw).

Secret areas exist in this game, so look out for them. It can save your life on crucial situation whenever you are low on health or ammo.

Collect ammo and health wisely, the moment you collect everything, you'll probably wish you didnt when you are low on health and ammo. Leave them alone if you are packed, come back later when you actually do need it.

Lives, dont waste them on something ridiculous. Such as falling to your death, which is a primarily worst thing to waste your life on unless you knew you were going to die anyways. If you do just load a game. If you lose all your lives, its game over. If you have lives, it'll bring you back to life, taking you to the checkpoint or the statue you saved at.

Checkpoints arent saves, so dont turn off your game lol. Turn off after you save, which is from a statue.

Turok is a strong swimmer, so he can go underwater for long amount of time. Enough time for you to search the area. Dont sit there too long though, he can die eventually. But it'll be a very long time. You'll know when the air meter pops up, then you need to get out of there.

The more weapons you collect (without sharing same ammo), the easier the game will be. It starts out rough at start but if you pull it through it gets easier. That I can promise.

Remember to collect ALL the keys, thats the whole point of the game and the way to beat it. You need those keys to unlock levels so you can access them, including the final level.

This is pretty much all I can give. As for glitches/bugs concerns, all I had was the white flickering screen and the link I sent helped me out with the problem. If you are able to play it, have fun.

I also give this 9/10, despite the glitch/bug but its possible to fix anyways. So its all good.
