24011354.review:
[b]A deceptively fast FPS about a dinosaur hunter, Turok, who also hunts people, large bugs, plants, mutants, aliens, robots, and demons. Sometimes and later it's a combination of a couple of those.[/b]

This remaster is probably the best version of the game so far, though I've never played any Turok game prior to this one. I do question why the [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_fog]distance fog[/url] is kept here and has to be kept on since I'm pretty sure most people's computers can run this remastered but still age-old game. There's an "Extended Draw Distance" option but that only lets you view a little further ahead. I've only seen a couple of enemies actually fire at me from beyond the fog so I don't see much reason to at least not have the option to remove that. At the very least the fog along with the graphics gives it that 90s feel.

A training mode of sorts is available that pretty much teaches you the how-tos of the game.
There's a prologue which after that's cleared you'll reach The Hub which is just an interactive level select area. There are 8 pretty long levels to go through with only 4 bosses in those 8 levels and the final boss only a minute after the 3rd's been defeated. 
Within each level there are 3 keys to collect for unlocking later levels, usually the next one after the current. The 7th level only has 2 and the 8th has none. While they're generally not hard to find, it's possible to actually miss a key as you play so if you exited the area or the level doesn't permit you to backtrack to find the missing key you'll have to exit the level from the end and re-enter from the beginning so you can do a proper search through. There's a "Keys" list in the pause menu that allow you to see which specific key you've acquired so you can pretty much determine which ones you've missed. Most of the levels are linear somewhat but they generally have plenty of side routes to sidetrack yourself to as well as secret rooms for useful items or otherwise.
As most FPS bosses go their fights aren't very impressive as they're mainly just run & shoot but the idea of fighting one here is a benefit in itself as it's a nice change of pace from the usual levels. Plus, concepts like fighting a cyborg t-rex is always a really cool thing to think about.
There's a dynamic map you can view that's really more of an outline of what you've explored. It starts to fill as you go through places you haven't gone to yet but as far as I know you can't zoom out and can only look at parts of the map that's around your location.

Except for the 8th level's case you can revisit each level again although everything you've picked up and done will stay that way. In a way, ammo and such throughout the game are actually limited and you can't conventionally "resupply" yourself but the game's [i]fair[/i] enough to [i]give[/i] enough to get you through, at least on Hard Difficulty and lower. However this can also mean that the fun in using preferred weapons can vanish fast especially when tougher & bullet-spongier enemies start to come in and it doesn't help that the amount of ammo you can carry for every weapon is, to me, really small even if there are loads of weapons to find & carry. Some weapons use the same ammo and two of the weapons have explosive ammo that apparently if you pick them up for said weapon you can't switch to using their regular ammo until you deplete the explosives first; the damage they deal is significantly higher but it just makes for BS reasons to conserve. You've got a knife and you can circle most enemies while slashing them until they die but that just takes too long.

The game uses a lives system though they're plentiful enough and there are a small number of places in each level you can save your game to. Dying respawns you to the nearest save point or checkpoint and a Game Over obviously means you'd just have to load from a save file.

There are various health items to pick up as well as overhealing ones and armor that replaces your health completely until the armor itself is gone. The armor here doesn't act like your health at all. The number the armor will represent will indicate how many number of hits it can take from anything before the armor disappears. While you've got armor equipped you can continue to heal and overheal until the maximum you can overheal is reached, which is 250. If somehow you die say from falling to a bottomless pit then obviously the overheal and armor vanish and you respawn with the default max, 100.

Plenty of neat platforming sections in here with many of the platforms almost impossibly smaller than one another. Of course plenty of these sections will have dangerous falls and few with bottomless pits as well as enemies firing at you as you jump from surface to surface. Ironically there's no fall-damage so jumping from any height to a surface below that's designed to be walked on won't hurt unless it's lava or some other hazardous surface. Even those don't do a whole lot of damage unless you're keen on staying there.

It's a remastered game suited and polished for modern PCs while still retaining its 90s game design charm with even a cheat menu being available. The levels can feel pretty lengthy and can get tedious since you're generally doing the same key searching over and over again only in different environments, but I do think the gameplay itself is solid with how fast & tense it can get. It takes a little around an hour to beat a level so the game can probably be finished in around 8, even while trying to find secrets along the way.

23944283.review:
This really surpassed all of my expectations. I remember growing up with this game - my parents wouldn't have it in our house, but I'd play it all night with my best friend when I'd sleep over at his place - and I only went into it expecting to get a nice nostalgia boost. It is, however, much, much better than I remember it being. Due to this excellent port, the ability to finally play the game with proper keyboard/mouse support, and excellent customization options for both the graphics and gameplay (setting the difficulty to 'hardcore' is very challenging), this version of Turok feels like the definitive version of Turok. It does not feel like an N64 game exactly - it feels like an N64 game reimagined and remastered perfectly for PC. Flying through the labyrinthian levels and blowing away tons of creatures feels nearly as responsive and fluid as it does in classic iD software games like DooM and Quake, and the weapons are cool and fun to shoot. 

It's a steal when it's on sale, but now, having played it, I could recommend this game for its full $20 asking price - even if the developers never get around to finishing and releasing the SDK. That's right, there is/was an SDK in development for this game. Heres to hoping it sees the light of day.

23913810.review:
EDIT: There's now Workshop support for this game, so the textures can be customized, you can get new levels and stuff like that, what's not to love?.

Oh boy, I might be blinded by nostalgia on this one, because this was one of the first FPS games I played, and to this day, still one of my favourites. 

Turok: Dinosaur Hunter is a FPS where you play as Tal Set, a badass native american with weapons ranging from a simple knife, to an explosive bow, to shotguns and rifles, alien weapons, a fucking fusion cannon akin of the BFG 9000, and even an ancient weapon with power to destroy the Lost Land, place where the game takes place.

You are trying to stop the Campaigner, an evil cyborg that wants to gather all the pieces of the Chronoscepter (Which you're trying to get) so he can fuse it with a weapon in his fortress to harness it's power and rule over the Lost Land. The Lost Land is some kind of weird place, where you'll find endless pits, jungles, ruins, ancient cities, robot fortresses, and all kinds of stuff like that. It's denizens are poachers, soldiers, dinosaurs, giant worms, killer plants, giant bugs, ape like reptile beasts, demons, aliens, natives, hell, all kind of shit is against you in this game. No regenerating lives, in game save points, so you can't abuse quick saves, and limited lives, quite old school. 

Now, I played this game back then using the N64 controller, and I was never really a fan of using a joystick in shooters. (Haters gonna hate) 
In my opinion, the shooting was kinda hard, and the platforming was a nightmare at time. Yes, I blame this game for my fear of heights, because some of those jumps are merciless, and if you miss, you plummet down the abyss. 

Now, this port feels amazing. Even if the graphics are kinda dated, because it was an N64 game, they gave it a few improvements, like water reflections, sun rays, and stuff like that. And I still managed to keep a smooth 60 FPS no mater how much shit was moving in my screen. Now, the controls are beautiful. Being able to play this game with a mouse and keyboard made those jumps way easier, and shooting feels way better now. I was able to pull incredibly accurate shots over long distances, something that was quite hard on the N64. 

The soundtrack is amazing, still one of my favorites from that era after all of these years. This game is sort of linear, mostly on the first and last levels, but it still forces you to explore every nook and cranny of the map, looking for keys for the next level or Chronoscepter pieces. 

The only thing I would kinda dislike about this game is that it's rather short. That, and the base price is kinda high, so I'd recommend waiting for a sale. But yes, maybe it's the nostalgia googles, but I really recommend this game.

23809329.review:
Warning, this game holds a lot of Nostalgia for me, as this was my second most played game on my N64 back in the day. (Turok 2 being my most played.) *I still own my copies and they still work.

Turok Dinosaur Hunter was, in my mind, one of the BEST FPS games on the N64. Some would argue that 007 Goldeneye and Perfect Dark were better, but Turok was basically the QUAKE/DOOM of the N64. Fast paced and total devastation to your enemies, which is why I hale this better than 007 and Perfect Dark. The quickness and speed to it and the feel of the weapons made it more fun to me than the others.

It may have only taken me 6 hours to beat this (on Hardcore), but as this game is burned into my memory from playing it so much on the N64, it was easy for me to remember were everything is. I already knew where all the secrets were, all the weapon locations, ultra health, tech armor, keys, etc so I was able to really rush through the game. The game is near identical to the original version, minus the first level. 

Close to the beginning of the first level, on your way to get the second key, they had changed an area completely. It had made me stop and think, how much more did they change/add? Well sadly nothing major that really stands out other than that one spot. Some areas were slightly changed here and there, but you honestly would never noticed them unless you were paying real close attention.

The game consists of traversing 8 levels, of which you run, jump, climb, swim, and shoot everything in sight. Collect 14 weapons to destroy your enemies, and kill the bosses. Exploring the maps to find the level keys, as well as secrets for more weapons/ammo/powerups.

All the original enemies are still there. All 14 destructive weapons are still there. The music that is engraved into my skull is still there. The same sounds, textures, it's all the original stuff! (Some fan made mods add some HD textures, which is awesome!) Some people may not like it that it looks outdated, but this is NOT a remaster/reboot. This is just a "upgrade" to make it work on PCs. No new content was really added into it, and nothing has really changed... But honestly they didn't need to change anything!

The plus side is since they smoothed out the graphical settings, it can pretty much run on anything. I boot the game up and it already selected my resolution of 1920x1080 60Hz borderless window, and runs at a smooth 60FPS. This has everything from FXAA Antialiasing, Bloom, Light Scatter, Occlusion Queries, a new water texture with new refractions and reflections system, and a freaking FOV setting!

FOV settings has a few choices. 47.5 (which I think was the original N64 FOV, which makes the game unplayable at this day in age, terrible motion sickness,) 74.0 (your standard console FOV,) 90.0, 110.0 (which is what I played at,) and 120.0.

Another addition to the settings adding a crosshair (which I didn't use), changing the "weapon bobbing" settings, being able to change ALL control imputes, as well as using "Extended Draw Distance" which can greatly change on how the game plays. With the extended draw distance you can see so much more of the world. Hell I didn't even know certain places had roofs on them! Since of the addition of the extended draw distance, the enemies have also been tweaked. They have been made to work with the extended draw distance so they would shoot you from a distance like you would as well, making it fair. This ALSO causes some enemies to shoot you from parts of the map that you would be going to later. It's not a major problem, but can be slightly annoying. If you really want the "Retro" feel on how it played on the N64, turn off the extended draw distance. It gives the game a different feel to it.

All the little tricks/glitches that I used/abused back on the N64 still work in this game, which is great. The strafe running, the platform shortcuts, the quicker way to get down long flights of stairs. The only sad thing is, back in the original versions, you were able to blow up people off the edges and make them fall into the abyss just because it's funny (to understand what I mean, look at the last screenshot on the store page)... Well they took that out.  Now when you try to fling an enemy off into the abyss, there is like an invisible wall that stops them and keeps them on the platform. It's not a major problem, just sad that I could not do that anymore.

From the little problems, it doesn't affect the game. It's still the great game that I grew up playing, and was nice to run down memory lane while murdering everything in sight. This game still a blast to play, and I will always recommend this to everyone to give it a try!

EDIT: There has been a new update that added a Level Editor and Steam Workshop support! Like, WHAT?!?! That is awesome as F*CK!

I've attempted my own hand at the editor, but it seems to be broken for me. Devs are still working on improving and adding more features to it in the future.

Pros:
- Same great game that I grew up on
- Fast paced Gunplay
- Smoothed out Graphics
- Same great soundtrack
- Old cheat codes still work (disable achievements)
- Improved Options/Controls fit for PC gamers
- Runs at a smooth 60FPS
- Map Editor & Steam Workshop
- Achievements (only 8)

Cons:
- Some may not like the old look
- Some minor sound problems
- No Steam Cards
- A little expensive

~~~~~~~~

As a message to the Devs Nightdive Studios, if they happen to read this review, THANK YOU SO MUCH for re-releasing this game, and giving it a ton of love and support!

23503385.review:
In 1997, Acclaim published a game for the Nintendo 64 and PC: a game called, Turok by Iguana Entertainment. It was a first person shooter based on the comic book of the same name. Set in a world with roaming dinosaurs, creatures, and evil tribesmen. Your character, Turok, is tasked with the simple job of stopping the world falling into the hands of evil. Evil that have, in their power, a weapon that’s as ancient as themselves. Pretty vague blurb eh?

Despite that Turok was a ground-breaking game, taking the player from corridor shooters such as, DOOM, and throwing them into a vastly more open world. It set a standard which made the series a household name, and changed the way level design worked for years to come.

In 2015, Night Dive Studios released a remaster. Unlike what normally comes to mind when you think of remasters, Night Dive’s work was more of a service, than bodywork. There was no super high rez textures, anti-alias tinkering, or insertion of HDR  sun-rays peering through tree tops. Oh no, this keeps its roots pure, it celebrates the graphical style and standards that the original carried back in the 90’s and, it even kept the controls as simple as the original.

It looks like the exact same game, but with a resolution, and smoothing fix, it feels like I’m back in my living room on my N64 as a child. Element which would need tweaking as to accommodate the changes in screen resolutions have clearly been prioritised;the HUD looks smoother, sharper than it used too; the overall game brightness is tweaked, brighter, with more vivid colours than the game could manage on it’s initial outing; the frame rate is smoothed, balanced throughout. All this combined with the slightly tweaked textures also come together to keep the game fast, flowing, and as easy to pick up and play as before. which helps with the game’s fast paced shoot outs, and the textures look a touch more detailed giving the world a little more character.

Read the rest: http://bigbossbattle.com/review-turok-dinosaur-hunter-2015/

23496014.review:
[h1] Back to the basics and it feels so good. [/h1]

As refreshing and soothing as the [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FIIt7q_NIbs]Water theme[/url], Turok encapsulates the FPS genre as it was in 1997. Like the long lost and older cousin of [i]Unreal[/i], Turok contains a semblance of an arena shooter but with a focus on adventure. There's no facade or pretense in this game. You are the Turok. You hunt dinosaurs but you also fight aliens, demons, cyborgs and robots, and pesky mercenaries. If that doesn't sound awesome I don't know what is.

And if you really care to know what else is going on you can figure it out as you play because it's real simple: [spoiler] Your mission is to stop a guy from using the Lost Land as a base of operations for a future conquest. [/spoiler] Does that sound like a complicated plot? Personally, that sounds like all the plot you need. Plus, the settings speak for themselves. Some are wide and outdoor. Some are haunting and morose. And some are sinister and cold like a machine fortress. Armed with a knife and bow & arrow, you set out and wind up using a quadruple-fire rocket launcher and the legendary chronoscepter. Wait, what's the chronoscepter? Let's view the manual:

[i]"The Chronoscepter is capable of creating micro-tears in the fabric of space-time, thus disrupting matter at a focus point."[/i]

Wait a minute, you get to shoot a micro-tear in the fabric of space-time against your opposition? How many other games start you off with simple weapons and by the end you're using scifi weapons and weapons that destroy time and space itself? Don't answer that because all you really need is the knife. Knife > Chronoscepter. The enemies don't stand a chance.

Overall, if you want to go back to a time where games were games, adventure and action was the focus, and it's you versus a wide variety of enemies that make you question reality itself; then the land where time has no meaning awaits. Become the Son of Stone. Take up the mantle of Turok. [b]NTHGTHDGDCRTDTRK[/b]

23338304.review:
I played this game for countless hours on the N64 back in the day, but trust me, this title is good for more than just a nostalgia trip. 

The game is in the same vein as the original Doom, plus jumping. Gunplay is reminiscent of bullet hell arcade shooters in that your main focus is dodging enemies and landing shots. Weapons work very simply with no reloading required. On top of shooting out the baddies, you also need to explore and solve puzzles to advance. Cover mechanics were lauded as a great advancement in shooters, and they are, but revisiting this gem from a couple of decades ago reminded me how much fun this simpler style of shooter is as well. It's clearly an older game, but it's just so damn FUN that I don't that a weakness.

As for the port, it's wonderful. I still have the N64 cartridge so I could do a direct comparison. The feel of the game is preserved flawlessly, plus modern enhancements to fix some shortcomings of the now practically ancient tech the game was made for. The pacing, movement, etc. all feel exactly the same as the original game. What they have done, however, is allow you to fully customize the controls. It works great with kb+m or a controller (I used an XBOX One controller and the default controls worked just fine, but you can reassign the buttons as you please). 

As far as the graphics...well, it's obviously a ~20 year old game, but it's from that period where games were charmingly ugly, and most importantly it doesn't interfere with the gameplay. There are also some nice modern enhancements here. You can choose to enable modern effects like bloom, shadows, sunshafts, etc. You can also enable an increased draw distance. This could almost be considered cheating given that levels were designed with the N64 fog in mind, but it's a welcome feature to keep you from feeling claustophobic if you're understandably not accustomed to the limitations of old gaming hardware.

The one place I would fault this game is the price. $20 is pretty steep for a remake of a game released before many current Steam users could even read. I'd say wait for at least a 50% sale, but at that point go for it, you probably won't regret it.

23319190.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Let me just start this off by saying that I've never played this game before it was released on Steam, so this review won't be from the perspective of a guy with nostalgia goggles, however I believe that my love for Turok is partially fuelled by the fact that I've always been a huge fan of the Quake series. I had heard of Turok before, but I never batted an eye until I saw that it was released on Steam. I took the plunge and bought it, and I'm so glad I did.

[h1]How well does the [b]game play[/b]?[/h1]
The gameplay in Turok is sort of what you'd expect from a mid-to-late 90s, no-nonsense first person shooter. Turok's gunplay is fast-paced and feels fairly fluid, however Turok isn't all about gunplay. Turok will put you at platforming segments or require you to explore in order to find certain keys. If heights aren't your thing then Turok may or may not be a game you want to play, especially in one of the later levels, and while Turok may not be as fast paced as Quake, it's definitely a game that will require you to be aware at all times.

You may die a few times in Turok, or even more than a few times. In other games, it'd be like "Oh no I forgot to save/quicksave and now I have to go back ages!" or "Oh no, it saved automatically at this boss and I have little to no HP left!" However, in Turok, there are checkpoints in the levels (and savepoints, don't forget those!) but when you die, you will respawn at that checkpoint with all of your health, but that's dependent on whether you have [b]extra lives[/b] or not.

[h1]What about the [b]graphics[/b]?[/h1]
You see, this is where the game sort of falls short, because even with the enhancements made to the visuals, it still doesn't hold up as well. However, it was mentioned that they improved the water visuals, adding reflections and refraction, and it blends in with the old-school visuals that the game provides. The draw distance is a minor interference but in Turok's case it can add to the tension with the platforming sections.

[h1]And opinions on the [b]sound design[/b]?[/h1]
Meh, it's something that could have been done better. I hate having to hear obnoxiously loud grunting while my character climbs up vines and transitions between caves and the outside aren't too great either, however other than that the sound design for Turok isn't too bad and it's passable.

[h1]Your [b]overall[/b] opinion on Turok?[/h1]
If you're a fan of fast paced, no nonsense first person shooters such as Quake, then Turok is definitely for you. This game is as old-school as old-school gets. It's a game that all first person shooter fanatics should play at least once. While the visuals don't hold up, the gameplay itself is the real deal. Though for a game as old as Turok, I would advise waiting for the price to lower. £14.99/$19.99 is quite a lot to pay for a game from 1997, but if you're new to the franchise it may seem reasonable. 23142770.review:
I never played Turok: Dinosaur Hunter when it first came out in 1997. I remember that it was considered a classic adventure game in first person and a technological breakthrough. Turok has been remastered nearly 20 years later. While the remastered version has graphically improved, it still is not up to today’s graphics standards.

The basic plot of the game is cliché and ordinary. The game stars a Native American who is up against an extraterrestrial villain named the Campaigner, who steals the Chronoscepter and ends up being scattered throughout the 8 levels. Turok must fight against dinosaurs and ancient people throughout the various levels which consists of temples and villages, but later levels look like sci-fi sectors.

In the beginning Turok may look like an FPS game, but it is truly a first person adventure game. It requires plenty of platform jumping in order to navigate each level. If you’re looking for the many secrets in the game you will have to do even more jumping such as jumping long gaps and many pillars. The gameplay and the environments feel old school and can provide nostalgia to those who play the 1997 version of the game.

The enemies feel old school and consist of velociraptors and mercenaries. The violence in this game is palpable, as you can see blood squirting out of the mercenaries as they die at your hands using the arsenal of shotguns, assault rifle, minigun, and rocket launcher. The enemy A.I. is good, but not great. Sometimes a mercenary will circle around you to hit you, but at other times it won’t. 

Other old school elements include the health pickups and ammo scattered across each level. There are keys to pick up in order to access subsequent levels. This means you can return to previous levels to find keys that you may have missed. The save stations are far between each other throughout each level. This means you will have to dedicate some time to the game before finally reaching a save point. There is no quick save feature to help you. Yes, there are checkpoints but they are only good if you die. Upon dying you will be returned to the last checkpoint you crossed. There is the old number of lives system showing how many lives Turok has left. This lives system feels quite archaic.

While this game is not up to today’s graphics standards, I do give Night Dive Studios credit for putting forth the decent effort for improving Turok’s graphics. The frame rate has occasional stuttering that can be a little bothersome at times. My FPS instantly decrease from 60 to 35, then increase to 47 and back to 60. It is a minor annoyance, but I think this problem could have been addressed in a patch.

I think Turok is worth playing again for those who played this game back in the late 1990s. The game is technically smoothed out and optimized for modern hardware. I think Night Dive Studios is on the right track when it comes to making remastered versions of games. At 20 bucks or on a future sale Turok would be a decent game to buy if you love first person platform jumping and exploration.

My Score: 7/10

23055029.review:
Turok is a true classic of the FPS genre. I have played around a bit with it as a child, but never really played it seriously. Instead, I had a lot of fun back then just putting in the cheat codes, unlock all weapons and cause some havok on the enemies. Seeing this gem back on modern systems with improved handling and support for modern screen resolution is great. The game still plays like a charm and has an odd but lovely personality to it. The game world seems to be one giant drug trip, which is quite entertaining to experience. The fluid movement, the iconic and - later in the game - extremely powerful weapons are still fun these days. Some of those weapons are just ridiculous, filling the entire screen with satisfying gigantic explosions. :D 
The levels contain secrets to find and encourage exploration. The soundtrack with jungle drums keeps you at a good pace. 

Talking about the value for the price: I think that this refresh is quite overpriced, given that the game just needed a few adjustments to work well on modern machines. I can see that aquiring the license might have had its price for the studio and that the audience is quite small, so the price can't be super cheap. Anyway: the game is super fun and I would definitely recommend to buy and play it. If the price tag is too high for you, wait for a sale - but Turok definitely deserves a place on your wishlist.

Ich dachte es wäre geil ein altes N64 mal wieder zu zocken und ging davon aus, dass die Grafik samt Gameplay immerhin geringfügig verbessert wurden - halt REMASTERED... doch ich irrte.
Es ist scheiße. Die gleiche behinderte Steuerung von damals nur mit einem neuen Controller der dafür gar nicht konfiguriert war. Mit Maus und Tastatur war das Spiel noch weniger spielbar... 
Ok, man denkt sich immerhin haben sie den Nebel wenigstens komplett entfernt, der damals aus performancetechnischen Gründen auf dem N64 eingebaut wurde, damit das Spiel flüssig lief. Nunja, das Spiel läuft zwar relativ flüssig, aber offensichtlich waren sie dann doch nicht in der Lage eine unglaubliche Weitsicht, bei den ohnehin lieblosen Leveln, von nur 10 Metern zu ermöglichen, dass sie trotzdem Nebel einbauen mussten... doch sie haben tatsächlich den Nebel remastered :D Er sieht besser aus als auf dem N64.... Man wusste also gar nicht, dass der Nebel damals einen Performance-Zweck erfüllte und nicht die Optik verbessern sollte.... Klar kontinuierlicher Nebel im Dschungel ist ja keine Seltenheit.... Remastern die auch Bugs? Oh, die Tür zur nächsten Mission damit das Spiel weitergeht, geht in nur 2 von 12 Fällen auf - lassen wir die Tür schöner aussehen...
Die Sterbeanimationen sehen genauso aus wie vor fast 20 Jahren und allgemein sieht alles irgendwie scheiße aus. Wieso sollte man auch ein Spiel komplett zeitgerecht remastern... Für 2-3 Euro würde sich der Kauf ja noch irgendwie lohnen wenn man tatsächlich ein eingefleischter Turokfan ist (insofern es sowas überhaupt gibt) 
Malt euch mit Buntstiften lieber ein paar Dinosauf Papier, schneidet sie aus und spielt damit im Wald - da hat man sicher mehr Spaß mit als auch nur 2 Minuten als liebloser Indiander, mit lieblosen Waffen auf lieblose Dinos zu ballern um sich durch den optisch sehr schönen Nebel zu kämpfen damit das Spiel REALTIV flüssig läuft.

22726036.review:
Turok is a fast-paced first person shooter in which you play as Turok, a time-traveling Native American man who's after a mysterious bad guy named the Campaigner, who is trying to screw over time or something. Beyond this, we don't get much story, the game instead relies on its gameplay.

Turok plays a lot like Quake or Unreal tournament, except the levels have a lot more verticality. Levels are very long and require a lot of platforming, usually not requiring much precision-jumping. You get a large arsenal of weapons including some interesting ones like the bow which shoots explosive blue arrows. You'll also get your typical shotguns and machine guns, which are good as well. You'll face off against dinosaurs, cyborgs, and alien-like monsters, all of which are fun to fight.

One of the main differences between Turok and other FPS games is that Turoks levels require that you find a certain number of keycards in order to unlock more levels. The problem with this is that the keys are very well hidden and often frustrating to find when you have to backtrack to old areas and face the same enemies again who respawn after a few minutes.

Besides this one complaint, I don't have anything else bad to say about Turok, other than the game is quite dated graphically, so that might turn off some players. The game is fast, fun, and surprisingly holds up well and stands toe to toe with Quake in my opinion.

Pick Turok up on sale and you're sure to have a good time.

Que c'est bon de retrouver un des jeux de son enfance (Ouai, à 5 ans, jbutais déjà des dinosaures à coup de Chronoscepter). Sortit en 1997, ce jeu n'a vraiment pas perdu de son charme et cette version PC est idéal pour (re)découvrir ce jeu culte. 
Il est toujours aussi sympa et fera plaisir aux anciens joueurs ou aux fans du genre.

J'espère bien que le 2 sera également disponible d'ici peu, avec son mode multi. S'il est mit en ligne, ça pourrait être super, surtout avec qu'on pouvait jouer avec un Dino (*regards sadiques*).

Petit défaut : même en mettant la sensibilité du joystick à fond, beh la vue se traine toujours ... un peu gênant quand un Dino nous prend par derrière (cette phrase est écrite sans aucune pensée bizarre ... bien sûr). 
Il souffre de quelques petits freeze de temps en temps, mais ça, ça vient sûrement de mon PC.

En résumé, de belles heures de plaisir, pour un coût raisonnable (vaut mieux attendre les soldes, parce que 19,99€, c'est quand même un peu cher), et un jeu très léger (370Mo) qui ne prendra pas trop de place.

22694793.review:
Das Nintendo 64 meldet sich aus dem Jenseits zurück!

"Turok" ist Nostalgie in reinster Form.
Die Grafik ist nicht zeitgemäß, nur hässlich.
Die Dynamik aber unvergleichlich!
Gutes Waffensystem! Verwinkeltes aber ausgefeiltes "Leveldesign".
Fordernde aber nicht frustrierende Gegner.
Dinosaurier, Berserker, Echsen und riesige Insekten trachten nach Turoks Leben.
Doch seid gewarnt!! Kein Held stirbt so bescheuert wie "Turok"!
Nicht wenn ihn Horden von Gegnern bedrängen! Nein! Nein! Das steckt er locker weg!
Er stirbt wenn er über Abgründe springen muss! Ihr werdet es erleben!
Also Fenster zu, damit euer PC nicht durch das selbige fliegt wenn euch die Wut überkommt.


Er wird versteckte Waffen in Höhlen und in Tauchgängen finden. In verborgene Winkel schnuppern um Munition und Lebenspunkte zu finden.
Schlüssel aus längst vergessenen Artefakten reissen um hölzerne Bollwerktore zu öffnen um sich in die weiteren tiefen des Grauens vorzuarbeiten.
Speicherpunkte rechtzeitig ereichen um nicht zu verrecken. 
Das ist "Turok"
Schnell, hart, gut! 
Ein Grenzstein in der Historie der Computerspiele. Oft kopiert und zum Glück getoppt!

Bei der PC-Version gibt es keinen Nebel sondern Weitsicht und eine sehr gute Controllersteuerung (X-Box) mit Twin Stick! Laufen und umsehen. Super gemacht. Tolle Umsetzung!

Seid gewarnt! Nur für "Turokser"!

Für alle anderen kann es zum leidvollen aber faszinierenden Erlebnis werden!

22640130.review:
Turok is a first person shooter that ends up feeling kind of like Doom.  I really enjoyed it as a kid, having owned it on the N64, but I don't think it has held up as well as some other games.

Level design is often just big rooms or hallways with enemies thrown around.  Some levels in the mid to late game are cool, but early levels are kind of dull and the last couple levels throw a lot of mazes at you.  Some of the keys you need are easy to miss and the game doesn't give any indication of whether you've passed a key or if it's still further up.  (I was missing level 3 key 3 and spent a long time searching for it because I didn't realize the level end portal teleported you to a boss instead of the hub.)  

There is a good variety of weapons, although many share ammo and some are only upgrades of lesser guns.  Most of the enemies don't feel very distinct, many are reskinned or feel the same.  As the game goes on, enemies get more health, so it's easier and quicker to just run past everything and kill only enemies that are triggers.

If you played it back in the day and loved it, it is probably worth picking up. If you have never played it, I recommend getting it if you like Doom games or if you really like old 3D action platformers.  I finished it in less than 6 hours, so keep that in mind.  This version adds a lot of convenient graphical and gameplay options that helps bring Turok up to modern fps standards, but if you still have an old copy you might be better off just playing that.

A fantastic port of a classic game, with a few extra bells and whistles thrown in to improve visual fidelity.  The core gameplay is largely identical to the original N64 release but there are a bunch of customisable options to tailor the experience to your needs. Has trading cards, achievements and gamepad support too.

Wicked soundtrack, ludicrous weapons, enemies falling from the sky, disco themed invulnerability buff, Chronosceptre trivialising the end boss - this is the Turok we know and love.

22509882.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
There have been many iterations of [i]Turok[/i] over the last 20 years, so first let's be clear about what exactly you're getting in this version of the game: this is a [i]remastered[/i] edition of the first game in the series, [i]Turok: Dinosaur Hunter[/i], originally released on the Nintendo 64 in 1997.  This is not to be confused with a reimagining or a remake; Night Dive Studios' mission was to clean up, repackage, and preserve the original game, and in this modest but noble goal they have succeeded.  [i]Turok Remastered[/i] is a faithful reproduction of the retro classic, which includes all of the charming glitches from the original but none of the technical flaws.  The game is optimized for modern platforms and has never looked better on an HD display.  Minor graphical touch-ups have been added, although they are very subtle.  All in all, this is now the definitive version of the game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There are three major elements to [i]Turok's[/i] gameplay: combat, platforming, and exploration.

Combat moves at a fast clip, as most areas of the game feature at least one respawn wave of enemies who will flank you if you backpedal from the enemies which lie ahead of you.  The enemy respawns are sometimes quick and occasionally relentless, but it never feels unfair since there are clear audio/visual cues associated with the spawn-in.  Adding to the frenetic pace is a very quick character movement speed.  Enemies can close distance in seconds and the player-character is equally agile and responsive.

The gunplay itself focuses on the player amassing an arsenal of weapons (found through exploration) and then frequently switching through the inventory wheel to pick the right tool for the job.  Unlike many modern First Person Shooters, [i]Turok[/i] places no limit on the number of weapons that can be in the player's possession at any given time.  Additionally, unlike many of its contemporaries, [i]Turok[/i] does not reset the player's inventory after each mission.  As a result, there's a continuous sense of character progression / growing strength.  Yet, the game also manages to gradually become more challenging as spongier, heavier-hitting enemies are introduced later in the game.  Gunplay in [i]Turok[/i] is just as much about being accurate as it is about managing and conserving ammo; if you use too many rockets on the middle-tier enemies, you won't have them when you really need them to deal with the bigger baddies.

Platforming in [i]Turok[/i] can be a particularly vexing mechanic, especially for newcomers.  If you haven't done a lot of platforming from a first-person perspective, get ready to learn the hard way.  Missing a jump usually means instant-death, and there is a whole lot of unskippable jumping in this game.  Not even cheat codes can help you get past these segments, so it's a skill you must be committed to mastering if you plan to play the game to completion.

Exploration is a large part of the game, and it's one of the most-rewarding.  [i]Turok's[/i] level design is smarter than meets the eye, often employing subtle environmental clues to lead the player in unexpected directions.  Some levels are more linear than others, but all of the game's eight major regions are full of secret areas off the beaten path.  Diligent exploration is rewarded with upgraded-ammo, extra life tokens, keys to open new levels, and early access to more-powerful weapons.  The trickiest and most-rewarding collectables of all are the hidden pieces of the game's ultimate weapon: The Chronosceptor.  It should also be noted that, while some of the mandatory pickups (namely: level keys) are easy to miss, backtracking hardly takes any time thanks to the extremely fast player movement speed.

[h1]Aesthetics[/h1]
[i]Turok[/i] was originally released towards the beginning of the N64's lifecycle when 3D gaming was still relatively new to the masses.  [i]Turok[/i] was one of the better-looking 3D games of its time, but to virgin eyes I imagine that it must look really rough around its sharp, polygonal edges.  Luckily, Night Dive Studios has cleaned up some of the original game's glaring technical flaws.  Most apparent among them are the oppressive fog and draw distance.  If you remember the N64 game fondly then you'll definitely appreciate how much easier it is to see where you're going in the remastered version.  No longer does the fog hide enemies standing five feet in front of your face.  However, Night Dive has tastefully decided not to eliminate the fog completely, preserving the some of the mysterious, haunting aesthetic of the original without compromising playability.  

True to the original, the music is serviceable enough but doesn't stand out.  It's thematically appropriate but not very interesting.  There's a lot of minimalist, primitive-sounding percussion, but the music loops too frequently and conspicuously to effectively blend into a subtle, immersive, atmospheric texture.  The sound effects are actually rather humorous at times, which breaks the mood a little but is generally joyful.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
This is a solid game.  And the remaster-- price not considered in this review-- doesn't come across as a simple cash-grab, in my opinion.  True, very little has been added to the game.  But Night Dive Studios has made too many considerate, tasteful decisions for me to be cynical about it.  [i]Turok Remastered[/i] is a technically flawless, unadulterated, minimally upgraded port of one of the great N64 shooters, and I recommend it to anyone who still occasionally revisits and enjoys playing the classics.

22286729.review:
"I! AM TUROK!"

*ALSO TL;DR: 9/10 game, GO PLAY IT! SO SAYS TUROK! SON OF STONE! *And so also says some asshole on the internet**

This game is amazing, and also pretty surprising...It is hard as hell yet its never super unfair, Secrets, save points, a good progression of threats as you go through each and every level. Eventually culminating in the final showdown, and how easy or hard it is well and truely depends not just on skill, but also on how well you know of secrets *The ultimate weapon *which only has 3 shots* Can only be used if you find all the pieces of the Chronoscepter* Though on the other hand you can cheat like a motherfucker and get the Ultimate weapon with unlimited ammo...and watch the game's difficulty suddenly just shatter like a wine glass.

Also knifing dinosaurs is pretty satisfying, even though everyone pretty much just autotracks you, they are pretty fragile, unlike you but they can stack up damage, it forces you to use every single gun in your arsenal even in the later levels because ammo starts getting scarce.

If I had any complaints, its more the feeling of some cheap deaths but if you know just what to look for, you actually can avoid that. *Also you can remove the Fog of War which helps LOADS especially in the final levels.*

Overall I give this game a 9/10 in my opinion.

21582446.review:
The game is solid, gradually becomes more difficult as you advance but gets cranked all the way up to 11 when you get to the last level. Having to go and look for keys or chronosceptor pieces that that you missed is a little tedious but overall it barely takes away from this fun game.

There really isn't a story that the game presents to you directly so if you're looking for what this game is about than I recommend googling it. It's there, but the game doesn't really tell you what it is. It just drops you in the first world and says "Figure it out"

21366597.review:
Turok definatly looks like its from 1997, but that older look just adds to the charm of the game. If you like older, Doom style games, you'll most likely enjoy Turok.

The story of Turok is very simple. You are Turok, and you hunt dinosaurs. The game starts you off right into the action with very little context on what is actually going on. This could annoy some people, but it doesn't pull away from the immersion at all. Although this lack of story can make the latter half of the game make little to no sense storywise.

Turok has a very fast movement speed which is a nice change from the sluggish sharpshooters from today. This makes the game playable at any pace you would like, whether you want to speed through or explore the levels.

When it comes to the levels themselves, many of them are fairly forgettable in design, but some have a genuinly interesting theme and layout. Either way, they are all fun to explore, with tons of secrets in every level.

The combat is responsive, and very satisfying with a large variety of weapons to find and use. As an added bonus, none of the weapons feel redundant or outshined by others (with the exception of a few), which allows a lot more options when you're tackling either a boss, a particularly beefy mob, or your average joe of an enemy. Turok also does a good job when it comes to ammunition drops, which seems like a weird thing to think about, but it manages to sit on a fine line, where i needed to be mindful of my ammo, but at the same time I didn't feel the need to be overly conservative with the weapons that I used.

While you will be seeing some of the same mobs a lot, there is a nice variety of enemies that keeps the combat from getting too stale and repetative, especially in the last few levels.

One problem I had with the game however, was that I wasn't %100 certain on what I was actually supposed to be doing. The game does a pretty poor job of telling you what you need to do in the beginning, and you can easily get lost on the first level. If you can get past this however, then it should be easy to figure out what you need to be doing for the rest of the game.

If you have played a lot of games like doom, then you will not be disappointed with Turok. If you are new to this style of gameplay, then Turok is an excellent introduction to other games like it. While Turok is not necessarily an innovative game, it is a fun one that does what it does well and is definatly worth the $20.

Mostly, Acclaim and Iguana Entertainment have made it more gameplay and goal heavy. Though the controls may be more simple, but overall, there are things that are enjoyable about it. Like for example, when I play through it, I got a slight sense of what the story was behind it. That was what made the first game so great. I notice that Iguana Entertainment has attempted to put together a story for the later series like Turok Evolution, as well as Vexx which was a platformer I personally enjoyed and wish Nightdive would bring that out on the Market. Their method of storytelling was... not perfect. However, they did great on putting in an assortment of other monsters than just dinosaurs, giant bugs and soldiers which I commend them for that. Not all good games have to have to be all cinematic. That's what I like about this one, and I admire how some devs are brinnging this back.

21145820.review:
I was one of the privelaged few who got to play Turok: Dinosaur Hunter when it was first released on Nintendo 64 back in 1997. It was one of the games that attracted us to Nintendo's quirky, but unique new system. While some preferred Goldeneye or Doom 64, Turok was still a strong competitor in the FPS genre and spawned a few successful sequels until plummeting into mediocrity. The controls took time to get used to, but the gameplay was fast paced and bloody, and it even managed to please longtime fans of the comic book.

Night Dive's re-release is like plugging in a 20 year old system again. Your memories begin flooding back and the first few minutes are glorious, but then the nostalgia glasses wear off and you realize just how far games have come. Turok is not a bad game in any way, it's just very, very dated. I love classic FPS games. Doom 2 and Blood still get playtime for me after all these years. Turok just has nothing that keeps it fresh after almost two decades.

I have no problem with the graphics, and applaud Night Dive for leaving the original design untouched. They even kept old glitches intact on purpose and, in a recent update, implemented the original N64 sound effects. Visuals and sound are still great. It's the gameplay that hurts. While playing on a mouse and keyboard is superior to the goofy N64 controller, and Turok moves pretty smoothly, some of the platforming in the game is near impossible. Some of the jumps you are asked to perform happen only by miracle, and sometimes just looking at a platform the wrong way can cause you to fall through it. The weapons are fun, but some don't seem to do anything or cause any varying degrees of damage, and just feel like they were put there to look cool. If you are lucky enough to assemble the Chronoscepter, good luck getting a hit in with it.

My biggest complaint is that the levels are TOO DAMN LONG. Level 8 wins the award for the longest, most excruciating level in video game history. It's neat that the levels are so open and there are multiple paths, but good god the last level takes almost two hours to complete! It begins to feel tedious after a while and you stop enjoying the game and just wish for the level to be over. Also, enemies respawn, making the levels EVEN LONGER when you have to clear the same corridors multiple times.

Turok is not a terrible game. If you have played it before and it's cheap, go ahead and relive some memories. Just be ready to cringe. It's very hard to recommend Turok to those who have never played it because it is so dated, but if you enjoy games of old and want a field trip back to when FPS games were still in their infancy, it's worth a look.

21090218.review:
Like the Son of Stone himself, Turok is a game from another time and place - the Lost World of the '90s where TV was  somewhat watchable, movies were occasionally okay, and games were (usually) shipped done.

Turok is a hardened Saquin warrior with a mystic lineage and a champion's spirit. He is the inheritor of a familial mantle that both compels and empowers him to -- well, you know what. None of that is actually important right now, because it's hardly mentioned in the game. And that's for the better, really. The comic books that inspired the game were absolutely all over the place in terms of tone and setting, as seems to be the standard for the medium.

Suffice it to say, you play the role of an awesome Native American warrior who handles ultra high-tech future weapons just as well as he does the bows and knives of his heritage. You travel the Lost Land - a realm parallel to our own in which time has no conventional meaning, and creatures and technologies from countless other universes coexist - in a quest to assemble a forbidden superweapon and use it to take down the evil Campaigner. The Campaigner is like a cybernetic Genghis Khan, only worse, and he's raised a bloodthirsty army to wreak havoc upon the Lost Land and beyond.

Turok was a technological marvel in its time. It's got wide-open spaces like Unreal and it sports the fast-and-furious run-and-gun of Quake, and it blends the best of those two games together. The result remains unique still today because nothing else out there plays quite like Turok does. It's not your typical shooter. Turok requires an adventurer's touch, as the game is just as much about exploring massive, mysterious hand-built environments as it is shooting velociraptors in the face with explosive arrows.

Therein lies the problem most modern gamers are likely to encounter playing this game. Turok is linear to a point, but the action takes place in fairly large, often vertical, outdoor areas, and it's easy to get lost if you don't pay attention. The game doesn't lead you around with big glowing waypoints, either, and uncovering the sprawling environs' many secrets is crucial to getting through the game without cheating. The game utilizes an atypical hub system that links all its levels together. Teleporters to the various lands are opened using keys Turok must uncover along the way. You'll need to find the keys that are scattered throughout the levels in order to proceed through the game.

If you lack the patience to explore - and you like your games on a leash - then you should know up front that Turok is probably not for you. But if you're anything like me, you're sick of modern shooters and their over-reliance on scripted set-pieces. I find Turok's open-ended, "archaic" approach to be a breath of fresh air so many years after playing it last. Exploring the world and finding a well-hidden secret brings a real, palpable sense of accomplishment, the kind of breath-stealing "eureka!" moment that very few recent titles manage to evoke even once.

The various levels are varied and interesting, and are underscored with an abundance of ambient sound effects and a truly bizarre drums-and-synths soundtrack that stands out on its own and is instantly recognizable. Though it began life as an early N64 game, Turok has atmosphere in spades. Its enemy design can only be described as eclectic. Velociraptors with cybernetic gun arms are awesome. Insectoid aliens with plasma rifles? Those are great, too. Sometimes, their armor malfunctions when you kill them, and they struggle against their inevitable explosive demise. Even better. Killer plants, overgrown bugs, armor-clad mercenaries with pulse rifles and tank-top wearing grunts with machetes - your opponents are always varied and never boring.

The entire experience has a hand-crafted feel, and everything is in its proper place. Though a shooter at heart, the feeling of adventuring in a bizarre otherworld is prevalent throughout, and the architecture occasionally reminds me of adventure games like Myst. Perhaps the rooftop village just reminds me of the Channelwood Age or something.

It's not all exploration, though. The action is fast and fluid with mouse and keyboard controls, and is super-responsive. It's a blast to blast away while staying on the move. Turok plodded a bit with the flaky N64 controller, but now the game is blazing-fast like Quake on the PC and somehow the game manages to handle the player's faster input very well. Especially if you bump things up to Hard - the setting has obviously been tweaked to be *quite* difficult in order to compensate for the player's better aim. Things get very tough, very fast on Hard, though easy and normal are just as I remembered them back in the day.

There's a respectable arsenal of exotic weaponry, which Turok literally stores in his magical Bag of Holding. No weapon swapping here. When I was a kid, my circle of friends derived much amusement from the over-the-top excess of some of the later weapons, what with their elaborate folding/unfolding deployment animations and sound effects. Whenever we thought of crazy, overblown weapons or machines, we thought of Turok and laughed. One of those weapons is essentially a portable nuke, and really has to be seen to be believed. Oh, boy, did that ever rock our worlds back then. Watching it blow over trees was exquisite. And of course there's a minigun, which you can unleash into the brush to reenact everyone's favorite scene in the Predator movie. And the ridiculousness of the more advanced weaponry actually serves to make the conventional all the more compelling somehow. Running around with an AK47 and blasting human commandos in the face keeps things feeling real, know what I'm sayin'?

This is a source port of the PC original by Samual Villareal. If you're a Doomer like me, the name will be familiar. If you're not, suffice it to say that the man is well-appreciated for his work on other source ports, and his involvement in the Doom community. Turok runs wonderfully well on modern PCs, and features some nice, subtle visual improvements that fit in perfectly with the style of the graphics. No ridiculous bloom or lens flares or anything like that - what's here is good enough to highlight that Turok never really looked that bad to begin with. Honestly, I'm surprised just how well it holds up, though the reflective water and atmospheric lighting really does add to the atmosphere. In high resolutions with anti-aliasing, it's a treat to look at. With about 500% of the colors present in Battlefield 4, my eyes almost couldn't handle all the sensory information.

So is it worth your time and money? Yes, absolutely. There's plenty to see and shoot in Turok's eye-catching, lovingly hand-crafted world, and I couldn't be happier with my purchase. And yes, I bought this game years after completing the original multiple times. It stuck with me, certainly. I'm beyond excited for Night Dive's rerelease of Turok 2. As much as I love the original, the sequel is even better. They're noticeably different, though, in terms of style and execution. I highly recommend anyone to get both.

21074125.review:
Turok: Dinosaur Hunter was a Nintendo 64 game made in February of 1997. This almost 20 year old game was one of the first 64 bit First Person Shooters and really pushed the graphical capacity of of the N64. This Steam port lives up to what the original console version was quite well. 
Turok on the N64 still holds up when returned to today, yet the control is pretty horrible to re-adjust to again. With the Steam port, you can play with a modern controller, and even use the joysticks, making the expirence better. 
The graphics, draw distance, hitboxes, and many more things have been upgraded to make the game run well on modern computers.

One thing however, while this is an old topic it is still relavent to new buyers, is the price. A lot of people think that 20$ (usually 15$ when it goes on sale) is real overkill. While I semi-agree I also played turok on the N64 and really enjoyed the game. Trying to find the cartrige online usually results in expensive prices do to a recent influx of retro collectors and gamers. I find the price to be moderate.

As a player of Turok 2, I cannot wait to see what the devs can do with that glitchy mess of a game.

20973338.review:
This review contains minor spoilers and self opinions!

When I first played Turok on the N64 in 1996 it was just ground breaking. Reading about the Remake and finding Turok on Steam 20 later is just awesome. I guess there are a lot of people who wrote already glorifying notes, hence I'll pinpoint out the differences. 

1996 vs. 2016:

better graphics: I'm sure there is an overview concerning the graphical enhancements (water, AAFX, fog, etc). The developers didn't enhance the graphics to much. Hence Turok kept its look and feel. For example the fog – originally designed to save comping-power – wasn't removed. But the player is provided with the option to reduce. Hence he still can enjoy the original games atmosphere.

more accurate controls: the PC Version in 1996 felt like a N64 port. Setting up the controls took some time and usually ended up in a half baked configuration – Uhm... jeah I cyn play with this, but I could be better. The remake controls are WASD-Style and work precicely.

aiming: opposing to the 1996 version the Player now can turn the crosshair on :)

the “mortal wound”: in the current version it drops very rarely, but this doesn't matter because this item was originally designed to increase the auto-aim-accuracy. 

Violence and blood-settings: opposing to the games PC Version in 1996 the current Version allows the player to chose red, green or “no blood”. Especially the German Players might be happy to notice, since the German Version was cut by removing Skins and blood effects to match the youth protection requirements.


I hope that Turok 2 will be remade soon and that the Developers port the bugfix concerning the Tranquilizer Gun.

20920500.review:
Was kann man zu einem Titel sagen,der ursprünglich 1997 erschien und nun neu aufgelegt wurde?Derzeit wird sicher der Begriff"Remaster"überall gezeigt.Aber es freut schon ein wenig,dass alte aber noch immer gute Titel neu erscheinen und die älteren Spieler(auch jüngere)durchaus in Erinnerungen abtauchen dürfen.Zunächst wird man sicher über die Grafik sehr verwundert die Augen reiben und sich fragen,warum man das damals so als Grafikbombe empfunden hat.Das liegt einfach natürlich daran,dass Turok zur damaligen Zeit eine kleine Revolution darstellte und die relativ neue Konsole"N64"medial einen großen Hype bescherte und infolgedessen für mehrere Nachfolger sorgte.Die Grafik war seiner Zeit gegenüber der ersten Playstation 1 schon etwas weiter und filterte Texturen mit Weichzeichnern und ohne Verzerrungen.Das sorgte für damalige Verhältnisse,für ein ruhigeres Bild und insgesamt schönere Optik.Natürlich kann die Grafik trotz der wenigen Neuerungen kaum noch heutzutage jemanden hinterm Ofen hervorlocken.Aber es ist das Leveldesign,was eine atmosphärische und dichte Spielweise ermöglicht.Viele der Gebäude und Texturen wiederholen sich sicher sehr oft,aber später fällt das aufgrund der immer größer werdenden Levels aber nicht mehr ins Gewicht.Die Levels werden nämlich stetig größer und sehr viel komplexer,was das Erkunden und suchen schwerer macht.Im Gegensatz zum original Spiel,wurde die Nebelwand deutlich reduziert und ermöglicht mehr Weitsicht in den Arealen.Früher wurde dieser Trick genutzt,um Rechenleistung der nachzuladenen Objekte und Details zu kaschieren.Heute allerdings nicht mehr nötig.Im Remaster dient es höchstens ein wenig der Atmosphäre und wohl auch um nicht alles gleich sichbar erkennbar zu machen.Aber stören tut es mich persönlich überhaupt nicht.Was die technische Seite insgesamt angeht,so wurde eigentlich nur Auflösung,Widescreen und 60 fps integriert.

Aber auch das ist ok und schmälert den Fun des Titels keineswegs.Meine Hoffnung setze ich allerdings trotzdem noch in die Modderszene.Da eben diese mittlerweile in fast allen Spielen wütet und sie sehr oft mehr als aufwertet,würde das einem Turok sicher auch gut tun.Stelle mir grad vor,wie die Vegetation erhöht wird und die Texturen noch eine Frischzellenkur verpasst bekämen.Als Krone dann noch eine Polygonerhöhung der Gegner,Saurier und Mutationen und das würde sicher dann nochmal den Wiederspielwert deutlich erhöhen.

Also ich kann Turok trotz seines Alters empfehlen,da es einfach nur Fun macht und als unkomplizierter Shooter sehr gut funktionert.Der Nachfolger"Seeds of Evil"ist ja ebenfalls in der Mache.

20900537.review:
This is my first playthrough of Turok: Dinosaur Hunter, I remember playing Turok 2: Seeds Of Evil for maybe the first couple of levels and watching the rest as my father played on the Nintendo 64. I've secretly loved this series from the sidelines for awhile now but now have a new revamped nostaglia to give this series a try. 

I hope that Night Dive Studios continues in their pursuits of revitalizing this wonderful series. Like some of my fellow steam users, I have the option of playing this on the Nintendo 64 for about ("$12.00") on eBay +shipping ("$13.00") or simply playing the existing copy of Seeds of Evil that I currently own and the thought had crossed my mind and  I assume yours as well. Although, I much prefer my computer over most consoles these days. For that extra $13.00. I want to believe it's worth more to support Night Dive Studios. 

What you are paying for is another copy of Turok: Dinosaur Hunter with enhanced graphics and gameplay mechanics. What your purchase means though. It is a contribution, that will help Night Dive Studio's continue to remaster the turok series possibly. Depending, upon the sales of Turok: Dinosaur Hunter and Turok: Seeds Of Evil. With wishful thinking may lead to another project in which there is a new turok experience. Say 2018. Feeling nostalgic, this game is for you.

 A young friend of mine, I was talking to him the other day about how great this game was and still is after 18 years.. What's Turok. So I barried him out backyard with my trusty shovel, no seriously this is a great opportunity to both preserve and showcase to the newer generations. Preservation of an "Old but not obselete" piece of gaming history. - Terminator Genisys

Gameplay Final Review: Normal Mode

   A fun enjoyable experience to remember, old school mechanics, no reloading firearms, ammunition and health a plenty, remember to save often at the hub and or during levels as they are pretty lengthy, lots of high jumps off of ledges and walking along cliffsides, simple yet sometimes surprisingly clever puzzles, step-on-that, step-on-this, collect that and secret areas. Swimming was an interesting mechanic that I thoroughly enjoyed. Loved shooting just about everything, tribesmen, the variety of dinosaurs in this game. Lots of enemy varieties so you will not be bored by repetition. Was surprised by the fact that the raptors regenerate. Collecting the Chronoscepter pieces is a nice little sidequest that pays off in the end. 

Ask me, is it still worth $22. I am satisfied with my purchase and have played at least 12.8 dedicated hours of this title, however there was an issue with the sound and was not available to me during my experience from the start to end. Which in all honesty was a little upsetting and disapointing after waiting 18 years to play this but overall a great experience. Bearing this in mind,  I am looking forward to the entire series being remastered, as well the next remastered sequel Turok: Seeds of Evil, I still have not passed Level 2 after all these years. Help me out Night Dive Studios with sound this time.

I want to believe, what do you believe in Steam users? X-Files :)

Note-worthy issue: 

- Sound cuts out for some reason? Quick fix, listen to the Original Soundtrack on youtube using your phone while you play. Although you will miss out on SFX of firearms, cutscenes and creatures as you watch them go through their scripted death rattles lol.

 - Night Dive Studios, released this title on steam as of December last year. This title has been on the market for a least one month

This review isn't going to be about the game but rather the modernized port itself.  We already know Turok is a classic.  

This port definitely brings what is needed in a game that was lost along the years.  The most noticable improvement was the removal and reduction of fog used to help performance on old PC's from the 90's and the N64.  You can now see much further.  The games frame rate is locked at 60 FPS with no way to uncap, thats a bummer, however it is understandable when dealing with such old software.

20801063.review:
Do you remember when cheat codes were a thing? Those were the days.

Turok was a game that I own on the N64 but I never really got very far into it so this release of Turok was something of a pleasant surprise. 

This port runs really well and has plenty of options for customization for stuff like the FOV, head bobbing and other neat stuff.

The graphics have been touched up nicely but they still have that quaint 1997 feel to them. 

Aside from a few performance drops the experience was nice and smooth with no crashing or anything of the sort.

It's a really fun and fast paced FPS with plenty of secrets that you could probably finish in 10 hours or less. It's a faithful port of the original but since there's no real extra content you might not find it worth the price point.

Also a word of warning: If you turn on a cheat, even for a second, Achievements will be disabled and you won't be able to undo it if you save like that. Making a second save is recommended if you want to mess around with cheats.

Turok, eines der besten Spiele zu N64-Zeiten. Ich weiß noch ganz genau wie ich es gesuchtet habe. Und nun ist sie da, die PC-Portierung. 20403347.review:
Overall it's worth a buy, but $20 feels like a little much, try to get it on sale for like $10-$12.

You're thrown into the game almost immediately, as you work towards the main level/teleporter hub. Hidden throughout the levels are keys that unlock other levels, which is your main progression. There is minor backtracking, but finding secrets feels very good.

Levels are actually fairly linear (eg, there's one core path, but several dead ends or branchbacks with powerups), but it's presented in such a way that you wouldn't ever notice this. There's lots of different weapons to use, and a sense of progression from weak ones to strong ones (assault rifle is basically a replacement for the pistol, automatic shotgun replaces the shotgun, etc.) and lots of fun endgame weapons to use, such as the Alien Weapon, Fusion Gun, and Chronoscepter. Levels also have really good pacing; you'll spend a good amount of ammo exploring and killing guys, then find a room that replenishes some/most of it. You never really feel starved for life and ammo, but you don't feel like its in abundance either.

Overall, probably 7.50/10. Not sure how much replay value it has, but it was fun for the time it took to 100% it.

20385724.review:
This review contains minor spoilers and self opinions.

As one of the first FPS of its generation, Turok surprised us with big enemies, big guns, big levels, lots of secrets to find and nice graphics back in early 1997. Turok has shown that the FPS genre is not limited to the Quake formula, expanding its genre with big open levels, keys, lives and a HUB, for exemple.
[list]
[*][b]GAMEPLAY:[/b]  In Turok, you are first presented in a forest. No intro, no cutscenes. The only story known is some great evil is taking the forest apart and you the Dinosaur Hunter should stop it. And that's about it.
In 10-30 minutes of progress through the first forest, you find out a place called The HUB where you can access any level at any time, go back to past levels and search for secrets that he left behind or keys to proceed to the future levels. This system may be nice, forcing the player to explore the level instead of just go through corridors which is very common in today's FPS, but if you miss a single key in a level you have to try the level again and again and again until you find it. It happened only once to me and believe me, it's annoying. 
You can't save the game everywhere. Instead you find especific places to save through the levels.
The weapon variety is great. You start the game with a single knife and a bow. As you proceed the levels you have access to better weapons such as the pistol, the shotgun and weapons go all the way to high tech plasma rifles. The [i]Chronoscepter[/i] is the ultimate weapon of the game that you can acquire it collecting its pieces throughout the levels of the game. Turok has a great balance with its weapons even as you proceed to the end of the game, making the player use almost every weapon he has until the end. It's fun and it works pretty well.
[b]The enemies are the weak point of the game.[/b] Turok has a low variety of enemies through its levels. The enemies change while you progress, yes, but their attacks are exactly the same even if the models are different, which is unpleasent and sometimes boring. The boss' battles are weak too. If you are expecting a intense and hard experience against the bosses, you chose the wrong game to play. Their attacks have a clear pattern and the boss get very easy when you find out its patterns. Running around in circles and shooting them until the end works well with every boss.
Still, the level design of the game is very well made. The levels are big. Not only that, they also have nice challenges with plataforms, lava, holes, fake holes, buttons to access secret passages, portals, fire, water and until the end of the game you will discovering new challenges which make the levels very interesting and different from each other. [b]Overall, the level design is what highlight the game into a satisfying experience[/b].

[*][b]GRAPHICS:[/b] Back in 1997, the graphics were great. The jungle, the animals, the fire, the water, the terrain, the weapons design, the animations, everything was made to turn Turok into a realistic and intense experience. So much that, that the Nintendo 64 had a close fog to the player and had problems with lag when the screen was full of enemies which could be annoying sometimes. Still, the enemies models are ugly with a single expression and their animations are very simple. This didn't bother me at all though, since it's still a 1997 game and I wasn't expecting much from it since most games from its time was like this. However, the weapons are very well designed and works nice together with the glowing, colored and sometimes realistic sprites. The textures have a decent resolution and it's not much detailed, I could point it as a passive point of the game's graphics.

[*][b]SOUND:[/b] The sounds are okay. The sound effects are not bad at all but it's not something to notice much through the game. The weak point is that the enemies voices get really repetitive as you progress but it's not much to be bothered though.
The music of the entire game is a bit intense with beat and drums that changes with every level you progress. They are not that memorable though.

[*][b]LASTING APPEAL:[/b] Since you need keys to progress the game, you will find yourself searching for every key through every level in the game if you want to get to the end of it. If you want to take the game a little further, you can search for every [i]Chronoscepter[/i] piece too and unlock the ~ultimate weapon~ of the game. It took me 6 hours to finish the game, find every [i]Chronoscepter[/i] piece and find half of the secrets. If you progress a little slower you can take up to 8 hours to do all this but not much more than this. The game offers cheats and about 20 secrets to find to extend the lasting appeal, but, unlike its successor, the lack of multiplayer can be unsatisfying to some people like me that likes to enjoy this kind of game with friends. All of this shouldn't go much more than 8-10 hours of playing time, but thankfully we're not paying a full price for this like back in the day.

[*][b]PORT:[/b] [b]Night Dive Studios made an excelent job reviving Turok.[/b] The game features new graphics enhancements like bloom, light shafts, reflections and SSAO which can be weird for some (I personally disable them) and pleasent to others. It works fluid 60 FPS everytime in HD resolution on my GTX 460 with no problems and no patches needed. The fog are way extended and if you don't like it you can use the old N64 fog too. The keyboard + mouse works exactly the way you expect them to work and the gamepad is now adapted to be modern-like FPS, making the Turok experience even better than the Nintendo 64 one. 
[/list]
[b]CONCLUSION:[/b] Turok is a great shooter even for today's standards. The variety of weapons, levels and challenges sums up to make Turok a nice and intense experience. The graphics are simple and not much something to notice to, but Night Dive Studios remaster brings new graphics features which can make Turok an entirely new experience from before without lag, HD resolution and fluid animations. The controls are simple and work exactly the way you expect them to with gamepad support. If you don't like them you can change it anytime in the pause/input menu. The game is about 7-10 hours long with every secret found. The price is just about right too. If you liked the old 1997 Turok, buy and enjoy this great remastered version.

[b]tl;dr[/b]: Great remaster of the 1997 classic. If you enjoy fast-paced action, lots of guns and challenging levels, buy this.

This brought back many memories. When I first played Turok on N64 I was probably just old enough to enjoy the game mechanics (I mostly plugged the cheats in, got all weapons and blew everything up). However I lacked the discipline to be able to navigate a lot of the large worlds and play the game it was meant to be played. Doing that felt great. It brought back a lot of good memories and felt good to beat the game the way it was meant to be played.

I knew what I was getting. Don't expect a huge new re-made game. Expect Turok: Dinosaur Hunter and you won't be disappointed.

Being a gamer who plays shooters on PC primarily, it's nice to be able to play an old favourite of mine. I have Turok, and Turok 2 on N64, and it's nice to play them with my desired control method.

What draws me to these games is their originality (native americans fighting dinosaurs, aliens, cosmic horrors.) and the colourful and epic weapons. The levels are pretty big and fairly linear, so you won't find yourself getting too lost, the enemies have decent AI (they roll to the side to dodge bullets etc etc) and if you shoot them in the right way they clasp at their neck gasping for air before dying.

The platform sections can be a bit irritating, but, they had those back in the halcyon days of FPS games, so I can't grumble too much about it.

All in all, a must buy if you loved the originals. and for those who haven't played a Turok game, give it a whirl if you're sick of the same cookie cutter 'realistic' modern military shooters.

Damals war es grafisch revolutionär und hatte dem N64 alles abverlangt deswegen auch der Nebel. Sonst hätte es die grenzen des N64 gesprengt. Ich hatte damals die deutsche Version und mich haben die Roboter überhaupt nicht gestört. Grafisch sahen die wie ich finde besser aus als die menschlichen Gegner. - Coole Waffen
- Hardcore Modus

Story gibt es zwar nicht viel aber in Turok zählt das Gameplay. Das beste an der ganzen Sache ist das es einen Map-Editor geben wird. Somit kann die Community neue Karten für Turok basteln und man hat ewig Spaß an dem Game. Eigene Kampagnen vielleicht eine die direkt nach dem Ende von Turok Dinosaur Hunter beginnt und und und...

Grafisch hat sich denke ich jeder mehr erhofft aber es ist halt nur ein Remaster aber wenn ich mir diese riesigen großen Levels anschaue die in ner High End-Engine...das würde auf jeden Fall ordentlich Leistung fressen. Meiner Meinung nach hätte den Levels bisschen mehr Vegetation gut getan.

Aber alles in einem geiles Remaster für Oldschool Fans zwar teuer aber ich finde für Turok lohnt es sich! Freue mich schon auf Teil 2!

This is a shoutout to Night Dive Studios for releasing fantastic ports and remasters of classic games for PC. Turok in particular is a fast paced and outrageous shooter that has large, branching levels, great weapons and is lots and lots of fun. The graphics, from 1997, are naturally dated and may turn off some people, but porting the game from the Nintento to PC more than makes up for it, I think, because aiming and controlling is far better and the solid 60 fps makes for a smooth, pick-up-and-play experience. Fantastic game. I haven't touched it since I was probably about nine years old and it's great to be able to blow through it again one more time.
