19753523.review:
This game is a bit overpriced at the time i'm writing this review, but if you like dinosaurs, shooting, climbing, bosses, blood spraying, jungles and don't mind the dated graphics, then i fully recommend this game. 
I liked the original Turok back then, so my nostalgia was tickled when i read this game would be remastered for modern pc's. I didn't expect fancy new graphics or high quality textures, that may explain why i'm glad it got released in the state it is now. The game plays great on Windows 10 at 60 fps and the controls have been updated to more modern standards. There's also some extra optional eye candy stuff, like bloom, sunrays, water reflection, extended draw distance etc. It also features achievements and steam cloud. There's no manual saving, instead there are save stations, so no save spamming. 
Overall, i recommend this game if you love Turok and don't mind paying a little more to put on your nostalgia glasses.

19753469.review:
[TL;DR AT BOTTOM]

This game brings me back to the summers of 1998 to 2001. I would fly down with my family to Florida to spend a few weeks at our condo. I always remember looking forward to seeing my cousin every summer because of the endless nights of gaming on the N64 and PS1 with no bedtime with him. I forgot how many hours we ended up spending on classics like Shadows of the Empire, Goldeneye, Dino Crisis... You name it! The one game that sticks out most to me from this time period is none other than Turok.

18 years later this game is as much of a masterpiece now as it was then, but I would wager that it takes an older breed of gamer to truly appreciate the admittedly clunky mechanics of what made Turok so great in 1997. 

This is a great re-release/remaster of the 1997 Acclaim title done by Night Dive Studios. They are more known for what they have done to the System Shock series, first porting them over to modern PC systems, and then announcing they will be working on a remake of the original. I would say that this is a proper re-release, but I have no doubt that others will clearly disagree with me.

Yes, this is a game that begs for nostalgia goggles to be worn-- but then again, this is the game as we imagined it in our young(er) heads after all, is it not? Coming back to play classic titles can sometimes be a depressing experience, as we notice flaws formerly looked over, or things that in general, just don't hold up. This is not the case here.

For starters, this game got a graphical overhaul. It runs on, reportedly, an entirely new engine. While most of the textures look primarily the same, it is a bit refreshed. Probably the biggest fix is the draw distance fog-- it hardly exists anymore and you can see heaps more of the game as it was intended to be seen. There are tons of graphical options to tinker with in-game, but this is hardly a taxing game by any standards. I am running the game at 1080P and it never dips below 60FPS. The "enhanced" graphics might not appeal to some, and may not impress others, but this was one thing the game sorely needed.

As far as I can recall this is about the same game we got in '97, I don't believe anything was added or removed story-wise. Gameplay however is much smoother. No more fiddling around with an N64 controller anymore, praize da lawd. Platforming is a breeze now.

I would like to say that this game and its playstyle will likely polarize modern gamers. This is probably not something the COD/Rocket League crowd would enjoy. It's a slow burn you have to grind your way through, similar to Dark Souls, but not as difficult, and more rewarding.

The sound design is notably improved, with a higher fidelity soundtrack, and better quality sound effects.

Native controller support is very comfortable and all the controls are totally mappable to whichever configuration you prefer.

If you want a great, classic single player FPS game to play, look no further, but just bear in mind this is probably not for everybody!

I would like to express my thanks to Night Dive Studios for not merely pushing out a product that was not touched in 18 years, but instead, putting hard work into bringing back the glory of the 1990s with Turok's remaster. Thank you!

TL;DR Section

Pros:
-Vastly improved graphics and gameplay mechanics
-Native controller support
-Well written, self-contained storyline
-Nice 21st century touches such as updated HUD
-Difficult, but rewarding and fun gameplay
-Dinosaurs
-Huge levels with emphasis on collecting everything
-Did I mention dinosaurs?

Cons:
-Textures do not hold up well at all. I would have enjoyed some refreshed textures
-No mod support (yet)
-No force feedback for controllers
-AI is hit or miss 
-No online play/co-op
-High price point probably a turn off to most
-Difficulty/playstyle not for everyone


9/10

19753150.review:
This is an update for the original PC port of Turok: The Dinosaur Hunter, which is in turn, a port of the original Nintendo 64 game. What you get is new visual effects like FXAA, water refraction and bloom though the actual base game itself hasn't been changed in the slightest.

At its core, Turok is a series of maze like levels with a short draw distance due to the hardware of the Nintendo 64, where you collect 2-3 keys per level to access 8 different stages before defeating the final boss. Along the way you collect a bunch of weapons, kill poachers, dinosaurs and aliens and search for the 8 hidden pieces of a weapon called The Chronoscepter.

Great game that is very much a product of its time, with limited lives, manual save points and a fixed health bar system. It's definitely not a timeless masterpiece but still an enjoyable game with a unique theme.

19752881.review:
Boy am I glad to see a Turok game on Steam! The Turok series are some of the most creative and mystical first-person shooters out there. Night Dive Studios took the rough PC port of this game and truly made it shine by adding support for modern resolutions, removing the 30 FPS cap, and adding several subtle yet beutiful graphical enhancments such as god-rays and realistic water shaders. 

It seems as though we'll never get a new Turok game that retains the creativity of the first 4 (the 2008 reboot was a disappointment). With that said, it's very pleasing to see the orignal Turok get a proper 2015 face-lift. 

If Night Dive Studios did something similar with Turok 2: Seeds of Evil (my favorite game of all time), my life would be complete.

19752858.review:
Initially released in 1996 on the N64 and eventually PC, Turok was a fantasitc game that showed real evolution in the FPS genre. Its levels were expansive, graphics great, the animation was fantastic, the weapons were badass, and it took place in the universe of the already awesome Turok comic series. The game was a system seller, and boosted the sales of the N64 console. Its PC release was a good port, but was not as well recieved as the console version, and unfortunately has not aged very well (the code it runs off of has a hard time with modern setups).

Skip foreward to late 2015, and Night Dive studios has brought this fantastic classic back from the grave, with tons of nice new graphics options, gamepad support, steam integration/achievements, and supposedly mod support is to come; something that the original would have from benefited greatly. 

All in all, this is a great and solid rerelease, and I can not wait for them to do Turok 2: Seeds of Evil

19750916.review:
I've been a VERY LONG and dedicated fan to the Turok franchise since I was a child. Turok and Turok 2 were my first FPS games I have ever played, and I played them repeatedly as a child and into adulthood.
I have every N64 game, PC port, Gameboy game, Turok Evolution, and even the incredibly average Turok 2008 on PS3 and PC. I even dabbled in the comics, toys, and collectables. 

You're, most likely, coming here from the N64 version of Turok, and that's fine. To be honest, there were few differences, even visually, from the original PC port and the N64 port of Turok: The Dinosaur Hunter. On modern systems, there were a few glitches with the PC port, such as the music randomly cutting off entirely, and some visual hiccups.

This PC version actually has some dramatic differences from the original game. First off, visually, it's certainly improved in most areas, and unnecessary in others.
The most important visual difference is the increased draw distance. HOLY CRAP was I surprised to see the game with increased view distance. 
Don't misunderstand, there's still fog, but it's almost doubled in the amount you can see in front of you. There was so much environmental detail obscured by the N64 fog that has now been opened for everyone to see in this PC port. 

As someone who has played Turok more times than I can even hope to remember, for possibly hundreds of hours total, I actually felt like I was playing a different game entirely for a moment. To new players, you won't be at all impressed. In fact, you will for a fact say that the game looks ugly and the level design is terrible. But for long-time fans of the game, this will rebreathe life into the game visually.

The next major change is the added on visual effects. This was mostly unnecessary, but I don't dislike any of it. There's now God Rays, Bloom, real-time reflections on water, and other visual effects. Sometimes they all clutter together in a bit of a mess, other times it looks rather appealing and colorful. 
Luckily, love it or hate it, these options are toggleable. You can turn off what you want and leave on what you want. You can make the game look as close to the original PC/N64 port as you want, even as far as turning the screen resolution down to good old 1997 graphics.

The next major change is in gameplay. The original game, on N64 at least, made use of slightly clunky controls that resulted in making it impossible to do any precise aiming. To alleviate this, auto-aim was present, with no on-screen crosshair.
In this PC port, there's still auto-aim, but I believe you can turn it off, and even put an on-screen crosshair. Since you'll likely be using a KB+M setup, this means you can finally aim (mostly) accurately with a typical modern FPS WASD setup.

Also, thanks to the VASTLY improved framerate (as this is on PC), moving, jumping, and shooting all feels responsive, and those first person platforming sections feel more possible than ever!

There is this horribly exaggerated headbob/sway. I know the original game certainly had headbob, but with the increased control and FOV it makes the sway dizzying to a degree. Strafing left of right has Turok fling his body and perspective by almost 45 degrees. Luckily, NightDive Studios provided and made the ability to turn this option off! Barely a couple days later they released a patch and now the headbob is completely toggleable, making the game much more playable to those who get sick from dramatic perspective shifts.

Finally however, there is the game environment itself. In the first level alone so far, there have been pretty sizable changes to enemy placements, environment positions, and even entire new sections of the level. Seeing these new areas made my head spin. It's [i]mostly[/i] what you might remember, but certainly changed. I can't say if I entirely like this or not. On one hand, it's a nice change of pace, almost like I'm playing the game for the first time again. On the other, it does seem to mean that a lot I thought I knew about Turok is mostly useless. It hasn't been too drastic yet, however, but we will see how that changes as I progress in the game.

The music is still fantastic, easily my favourite percussion based soundtrack in any game EVER, fitting each level perfectly. Textures and character models are sharper and cleaner, but are exactly the same from 1997. Sound effects are also the same, though the sound design as a whole has been tweaked for the better to be more crisp.

I do have a few nitpicks:
1. No walk toggle. This was crucial in some of the platforming sections, and it seem Turok's movement speed has been slightly increased otherwise.
2. The earlier mentioned headbob/sway. 
3. Gamepad controls feel floaty and imprecise.
4. The map overlay shows in areas that in the previous port didn't. For examples, in the original port there were certain areas where the map did not draw, forcing you to explore, mostly in maze like areas. To 98% of players, this might be a great change, but for the 2% that have brain damage like myself, we might prefer the areas where we couldn't rely on the map.

Overall, this is still Turok, one of the greatest old-school first person shooters I've ever played, and can only be topped by it's sequel, Turok 2: Seeds of Evil (Please be swift Nightdive Studios!!!)

I WANT to recommend this game to newcomers, but I'm afraid most of them will shit all over it for being old and outdated. 
This is really meant to be a game for the fans and nostalgic players, of which there are many.

Edit about Price (12/17/2015): A friend of mine mentioned about the price. Currently, on release, it's sitting at $16 on sale, and $20 normally.
Personally, I find that $15 should be the standard price, and they could have done $10 on sale. Other people would disagree and say $10 should be the base price.
I feel $15 is fair, for a couple reasons.
1. The original PC port of Turok is sitting between $20-40 depending on where you look. There are a few areas where it's cheaper, but the only one I found was from Italy.
2. The original PC port isn't guaranteed to work. I know personally I had issues getting the soundtrack to keep playing during gameplay
3. This isn't using the original engine, meaning some work had to be put in, especially to slap on those graphical effects and the change things around. This isn't a simple updated port, there are things literally changed from the source material.

19750581.review:
[h1][u]TUROK: DINOSAUR HUNTER[/u][/h1]

[h1]STORY[/h1]Der Indianer Tal'Set wird auserkoren, der nächste Turok zu sein: der Schützer der Barriere zwischen Erde und dem verlorenen Land. Das verlorene Land, ein Land in dem das Böse herrscht und Zeit keine Bedeutung hat, wird von einen finsteren Herrscher namens "Campaigner" beherrscht. Dieser will mittels des "Chronozepters" die Struktur der Zeit zerstören und so die Herrschaft des Universums an sich reißen. Turok muss dies verhindern und stellt sich der Armee des Campaigner, welche aus Bestien wie Dinosauriern und Aliens besteht. Wird Turok es schaffen, die Pläne des Campaiger zu vereiteln und ihn zu schlagen?

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]Turok: Dinosaur Hunter ist ein schneller FPS-Shooter, der sich auch bestens für Speedruns eignet. Ihr habt die Wahl zwischen 15 Waffen, die nach und nach gefunden werden können. Das Gameplay wird aufgelockert durch gelegentliche Rätsel sowie Geschicklichkeits-Einlagen. Es gibt 8 Level (In der Remaster Version leicht verändert) sowie 4 Bosskämpfe. Während die Bosskämpfe alle relativ ähnlich ablaufen, unterscheiden sich die einzelnen Level in den meisten Fällen stark voneinander.

[h1]TECHNIK[/h1]Da es sich um eine Remaster-Edition handelt, wurden Grafik, Steuerung und Kompatibilität unter modernen Betriebssystemen verbessert. Was bei Steuerung und Kompatibilität gut geglückt ist, ist bei der Grafik leider nicht gelungen: lediglich höhere Auflösungen wurden hinzugefügt, Bloom und FXAA Effekte ergänzt sowie der Nebel abgeschwächt und so die Sichtweite erhöht. Da die Texturen und Effekte sehr altbacken sind, könnte dies den ein oder anderen Spieler abschrecken. Außerdem ist noch zu erwähnen, dass es sich hier (auch in Deutschland) um die Uncut-Version handelt.

[h1]FAZIT[/h1]Meiner Meinung nach, einer der besten FPS-Shooter oder gar eines der besten Spiele aller Zeiten, leider aber durch die altbackene Grafik wohl für die Wenigsten zu empfehlen.

Für Fans von Shootern "der alten Schule", Nostalgiker und Dinosaurier Fans.

19750570.review:
The best way to play Turok. 

The first time I really play Turok 1. I've always been a Turok 2 fan, and I gotta say, with modern control schemes It's a lot more enjoyable and killing enemies is still really satisfying. Graphically it has aged gracefully. Even the platforming sections are not as annoying as they were before but are still really bad. The keys to unlock new levels are hidden in some sadistic areas at times, and replaying the levels over and over again is frustrating. The difficulty is somewhat lower than the original, mainly because of the modern control scheme. Dying to an enemy is actually really rare and most death will be mainly due to bad platforming sections.

The pricetag of 14.99 is honest, but when the sales are over, the game will raise it's pricetag to a less honest 19.99. The game is still great, and it definitely deserves 19.99 but it will be hard to convince someone to purchase Turok over, let's say, Resident Evil Rebirth.

The gameplay shows it's age at times, but when you blast an enemy with the automatic shotgun and seeing him coughing up blood will never get old. The game is gory and it is absolutely satisfying to kill people in this game. Being lost in this huge map, looking for the key that is hidden on a hidden platform can be really frustrating but when you kill enemies, that's where the game really hits the spot.

I recommend this game, but I recommend even more it's sequel, Turok 2. Since it's Turok 1 but better at every point. No more key hunting but objectives to do, you can dismember enemies (which is really awesome), a ridiculous amount of weapons etc...

The port runs great, has tons of graphical settings and is very nice to look at. 

I can't thank enough Kaiser and the guys at Night Dive Studios for what they do.

39174456.review:
Having played Turok: Dinosaur Hunter on the N64 when it came, I was excited to see this remaster in the Steam Store. 

Likes: The run-and-gun gameplay, the weight and momentum of jumping, and the variety of weapons in this game scratches an itch for me. I've been switching between a Logitech Game Pad, Steam Controller and the mouse and Keyboard for controls, and I can't really say that any of those options don't fit this game. If you want a certain feeling when controlling the game I would highly recommend getting in the training level and tweaking all the settings you need before starting the main game. I ended up doing this for the Steam Controller for the look sensitivity. Also, the levels are similar enough to the original that I was running through the first 4 on memory alone. 

Dislikes: I am sad to say that I noticed that the sounds that certatin objects and enemies make in this game are not the same as the sounds from the original for some reason. The Pur-Linn, Raptors, and Human enemies all make the same sounds, and most of the weapons make the same sounds when firing. The Save Points and the Checkpoints do not make the same noise as the original, particularly when resurrecting Turok after a death.  It's an extremely minor point that I 'm nitpicking on looking for something to complain about. The fact that the main character screams " I...AM TUROK!!!" when gaining an extra life was honestly enough for me. 

If you have never played a game from the N64 library, I can't recommend this enough as an "early" 64 game. The remaster has made it possible to run this well on modern hardware and with modern settings (no 680X480 CRT's available at my house anymore!) so this is the best way to experience something this old without frustration. 

Play this if you like other FPS games from the era, like Quake(1996), and Unreal (1998).

39023177.review:
This is the first game I’ve ever seen on Steam that I used to play a lot as a kid, and I loved it. I could never get past level five, though, because I was missing a key in either level four or five. Once I bought it here, I couldn't wait to dive into it, even though my experience was slightly different, because of the mouse and keyboard controls, and I didn't use cheat codes like I always used to.

So the main objective in this game is to find a bunch of keys to access the different levels in the hub world. There are eight levels altogether, and they all have the exact same mission: Find the keys and leave. The levels aren’t particularly interesting to talk about. You have a jungle, ancient city, ruins, and blah blah blah. The Treetop Village is where I had never gotten to before. You see more cliffs at the start of that level than trees.

Each track from the soundtrack fits perfectly with each level they are in. Some tracks are so upbeat, like in the Jungle level. It actually sounds like a jungle, especially with all the animal sounds. Others can sometimes be quieter, like in a cave. Even going underwater has its own track. 100 gold stars for this composer.

The way the camera moves when you start can be a little disorienting, but luckily, that can be turned off in the "Head Bobbing" options.

If you pick up enough triangles, which I like to call "Doritos", you gain an extra life. You also pick up chronoscepter pieces, weapons, backpacks to carry more ammo, and spiritual invincibility, which is quite useful, since it slows down enemies and makes you invulnerable to their attacks. There is one chronoscepter piece in each level. I won't say much about it, but I will say that if you can get the chronoscepter, good things will happen. I thought the infinity symbols were level 8 keys, but it turns out there aren’t even that many of those keys. Those symbols are actually the chronoscepter pieces. Well, that’s kinda misleading, isn’t it? What is a list of chronoscepter pieces doing in the “Keys” page?

You have a variety of weapons to choose from. You got your old fashioned weapons, like the knife and bow. You’ve also got your military weapons, like the pistol, shotguns, assault rifle, and so on. Some of these weapons become useless due to other weapons using the same ammo, like the pump action rifle, and the pistol. Just use the auto shotgun and assault rifle, they’re much more superior. But there are also plasma weapons. Such colors! Much power!

There are many different kinds of enemies in this game. You start off fighting just regular guys with guns, raptors, leaping lizards, and giant mutant gorillas. But the enemies get tougher in each level, the bosses being the hardest. The boss fights mostly consist of running backwards and just unloading everything you’ve got on them. You will have to do a lot of strafing to avoid being hit by their attacks. Some of the bosses have unavoidable attacks, because that’s totally fair. But oddly enough, those do the least amount of damage, as far as I’ve seen, at least.

There is a lot of puzzle solving you have to do to get goodies. Usually, you will have to look around for a platform to jump from to reach them, or look in all the nooks and crannies for a button, a secret path, a portal, or all of the above to get to those hard to reach places. But there are other secret ways to get goodies too. There are invisible platforms, walls you can walk through, platforms to land on down below, and areas you need to strafe-jump to in order to get to them. There are all sorts of ways to get goodies.

Each level has two bonus areas, in which you have to enter a floating blue portal to get to. You can get some goodies here too, but there is usually an obstacle course or platforming section that you will need to pass in order to get to the good stuff. Each time you enter the portal, it alternates between the two areas. The goodies don’t respawn, so unless you missed some, or you need to regain health or Doritos, there’s really no point in entering them a second time.

Apparently, you can unlock cheats in this game. When you get 9 lives and 99 Doritos, you will unlock the "Infinite Lives" cheat. That's actually pretty cool. I didn't know cheats could be unlocked like that. Unfortunately, that's the only cheat I was able to unlock.

That's actually all I am going to say about this game. This was definitely a real nostalgia trip for me. It’s just as much fun as I remember, if not more fun now than it was back then. I am so glad that someone decided to act on bringing this game back to us consumers who loved the original Nintendo 64 version. I could probably give this game a straight up 10 outta 10. Well, maybe a 9 because of the respawning enemies. That can still be kind of annoying.

38002879.review:
Turok es probablemente uno de los grandes clásicos de los FPS de los 90', una era donde grandes nombres como Doom o Quake, Goldeneye 007, Unreal o Half-Life cimentaban las bases del género con un estilo que hoy solo vemos a cuentagotas con títulos como el reciente DOOM: títulos "fast-paced" con escenarios intrincados, secretos, items y power-ups a recolectar, llaves y otros objetos necesarios para avanzar, y un arsenal permanente donde destacaba la creatividad y el poder de destrucción con cifras que solían oscilar entre la decena y un par de docenas de armas letales. Turok: Dinosaur Hunter nos traía todos estos elementos, y lo hacía utilizando una licencia que probablemente muchos desconocen, pero que tiene un trasfondo bastante curioso.

Y es que si queremos conocer el pasado de Turok no debemos y a la década de los 90', sino a la de los 50', donde se publicó por primera vez un cómic utilizando el personaje de Turok en 1954, y dos años más tarde con su propia historia. Las bases para los juegos ya se habían establecido, un mundo de aspecto prehistórico mezclado con ciencia ficción y un héroe con un atípico aspecto nativo americano, en este caso llamado Tal'Set y que sería nuestro Turok. A pesar de que el videojuego se basa en una novela gráfica con décadas s sus espaldas (y que sigue teniendo apariciones hoy en día), su plano argumental está tan trabajado como los de un clásico Doom o Quake, es decir, completamente ausente, lo cual puede considerarse por algunos una oportunidad desperdiciada pero que por otro lado asegura una jugabilidad directa y rápida en lo que nos interesa: acción, acción y acción.

Turok es completamente Old School y eso se nota desde el principio, con un estilo de juego rápido, controles básicos y simples en su ejecución y decenas de enemigos abordándonos, pero también presentaba en su día cualidades que le daban una identidad marcada más allá de sus enemigos (esa híbrida fauna que va desde dinosarios a humanos e incluso aliens, robots y otras alimañas) o sus escenarios se aspecto marcadamente prehistórico. La arquitectura de los niveles era enorme y compleja, y encerraba muchos secretos, algunos vitales para avanzar como sería la búsqueda de las llaves, nuestro principal objetivo en cada nivel, o las piezas del Chronoscepter, un arma que, en caso de conseguir ensamblarla, nos será clave en un momento dado. Para ello el equipo de Iguana Entertainment creó un surtido de 8 niveles que quizás en cantidad pareciese poca cosa para la época, pero cada uno de ellos era largo e intrincado. Por lo general todos ellos pueden durarte más de media hora y no pocas veces menos de la hora de duración, sobre todo si nos perdemos o nos quedamos absortos explorando, algo nada fuera de lo común.

Aunque el cómputo global del juego puede durar menos de 10 horas sin problemas a poco que sepas orientarte, utilizar el mapa, o simplemente sin entretenerte más de la cuenta, la longitud de los niveles es verdaderamente remarcable, la estructura de algunos era especialmente espectacular, sobre todo en casos como el de The Treetop Village con escenarios con un enorme grado de verticalidad (algo inusual en general) o The Final Confrontation, un auténtico laberinto alienígena que pondrá de los nervios a aquellos que no sepan encontrar la salida. Puede que sea un factor que irrite a algunos, pero un diseño de escenarios como este siempre es especial, y además sería la base sobre la que se cimentaría una saga tan emblemática como es la de Metroid Prime (hecho por Retro Studios, fundada por muchos miembros de Iguana Entertainment). De hecho, Turok tiene especial énfasis en aspectos no tan propios de los FPS, como cierta tendencia a las plataformas, algo que normalmente tiene un plus de dificultad cuando no ves claramente por donde pisas, pero que sería trasladada a la sub-serie en primera persona de Samus Aran con todas las variantes que ofrece la saga de Nintendo.

Otro de los aspectos destacables es el arsenal del juego, que cuenta con muchas armas, la gran mayoría de ellas reconocibles y básicas en cualquier FPS que se precie, como pueden ser pistolas, escopetas, rifles o lanzacohetes. Sin embargo Turok tiene algunas particulares como es el caso del arco Tek, el cual contará con flechas normales y flechas explosivas, haciendo de esta última variante especialmente eficaz. Otros como el Cañón de Fusión se siente como una variante propia del BFG de ID Software, y por supuesto está el mencionado Chronoscepter, aunque conseguirla justo en las últimas secuencuas del juego hace que en general sea un recurso muy desaprovechado y una anécdota más que otra cosa. Sin embargo, en el arsenal hay gran variedad y te será de utilidad frente a oleadas enemigas que no solo son numerosas, sino que además pueden reaparecer, lo que hace que en el caso de que tengas que hacer Backtracking, no sea un paseo sin más.

Los peores apartados sin duda están en el lado técnico. El audiovisual es el elemento que más tendencia tiene a envejecer, y en el caso de las primeras generaciones de FPS tridimensionales, es muchísimo más notable, no solo por los modelados que se sienten como una masa poligonar que apenas pueden ser capaces de respetar los términos básicos de la anatomía humana (o la dinosauria en este caso), sino en general escenarios, texturas, etc... todo se siente como en plena década de los 90, y el remaster no es que haga grandes cambios y mejoras, se siente una remasterización con lo básico y fuera. Peor aún si pensamos en el hecho de que a veces el rendimiento no es todo lo excelente que debería esperarse de un juego que ya tiene sus 20 años en la chepa, y a veces he visto cómo los 60Fps tenían algunas ocasionales bajadas a 50-55 FPS, lo cual no debería ser así. Por lo demás, tampoco puedo hablar al dedillo de todos los cambios que hay respecto a las versiones originales del juego ya que apenas jugué al original en su día, aunque creo que es de cajón que han quitado bastante niebla que, en su día, se usaba para aliviar la carga gráfica del juego y no desplomar el rendimiento de este.

Pero más que el visual que hasta cierto punto me parece comprensible, me resulta chocante el sonoro. Especialmente la banda sonora no a envejecido bien, no tiene temas memorables y creo que si lo comparo con el de la secuela palidece por todas partes, pero además la calidad del audio se siente mala, como "vieja", por lo que tampoco parece que se haya hecho un gran trabajo en el remaster de ese aspecto. Los efectos sonoros se sostienen mucho más aunque también se sienten desactualizados. 

A grandes rasgos Turok es más convincente para aquellos que vivieron la época dorada de los FPS en plena época "Quake" con todos los ingredientes de aquellos, y mientras nuevas generaciones encontrarán viejo y desfasado más de un aspecto del juego, los nostálgicos podrán revivir uno de los títulos más emblemáticos de la época con todo el sabor de antaño. Las nuevas generaciones que se atrevan a explorar estos clásicos también encontrarán un título de acción de ritmo rápido y con especial énfasis en la exploración e incluso los plataformas, con un gran repertorio de armas y enemigos variados. Si te consigues anteponer a un apartado técnico que caducó hace muuuucho tiempo, es un gran juego que te transportará al pasado (en más de un sentido) sin necesidad de una máquina del tiempo.

Si quieres unirte a mi grupo de Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/JoshCell

Si quieres seguirme como mentor en Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/29569915-Josh-Cell/

40623128.review:
Allá en el año 1997 los juegos tipo FPS no eran habituales en consolas y Turok (nombre del protagonista) fue un éxito en Nintendo 64 por su apartado técnico y ambientación con dinosaurios. Turok proviene del mundo de los comics y quizá por ello el juego va directo a la acción y se ahorra completamente la historia.

El objetivo es abrir los 8 portales que dan acceso a los niveles y en ellos buscar las piezas de una máquina llamada Chronoscepter, por ello la exploración será gran parte del juego aunque podemos revisitar los portales ya abiertos cuando queramos. Tiene un estilo muy arcade, no veremos enemigos en gran cantidad pero se regeneran si pasamos rato sin avanzar, la munición es escasa y nos obliga a ir cambiando de arma según el enemigo para ser más efectivos. La música acentúa mucho el estilo arcade con melodías de rítmos rápidos. Esta versión de Steam permite activar algunas opciones extra, por ejemplo el balanceo del arma mientras caminamos, un punto de mira, hacer que los impactos sean precisos, alterar la saturación de colores o elegir entre varios idiomas, interesantes mejoras que no estaban en el juego original, solamente se echa en falta recargar las armas manualmente. Incluso hay un apartado especial de trucos en el menú que se activan con códigos, desconozco donde encontrar esos códigos pero jugando de forma normal (reuniendo muchas vidas) me han dado el de "vidas infinitas".

Su paso al PC hace que el juego sea más fácil que como fue concebido con el mando de la consola, no solamente por la facilidad para apuntar sino por tener una tecla disponible para cada arma pudiendo cambiar rapidamente entre ellas, por suerte el sistema de puntos de guardado si hace que la dificultad se mantenga. La niebla densa es una característica técnica del juego que era la forma de hacer posible sus gráficos 3D en la consola, en PC es algo prescindible pero no se puede desactivar (aunque la distancia de visión es algo mayor que en la versión original), pero sobretodo gráficamente está muy desfasado, se notan los escenarios muy vacíos y los enemigos demasiado simples.

Resumiendo, su fuerte era un apartado técnico que no sorprende a estas alturas y si eres aficionado al género no te aportará nada nuevo, aunque tampoco abundan juegos con esta temática y entretiene con su combinación de FPS, plataformas y exploración.

40457268.review:
I remember having a friend who owned this game on the Nintendo 64, and how jealous I was that his parents let him play it. His mom hadn't noticed the blood coming from Turok and the dinosaur he was strangling on the cover of the box, and he had turned off the blood in-game so she wouldn't see it. We played it for hours, and we forgot all about my Playstation 1 with a variety Disney games, and the copy of Grand Theft Auto that I had hidden inside of a Donald Duck game. 

In short, we spend hours going over every nook and cranny to find every secret and outdo each other as the true dinosaur hunter. And surprisingly that's exactly what I went back to after picking up this remaster, I spend hours running through the same map trying to find keys so I can move to the next level. Not because of achievements, XP points, or skins, but because I wanted to be able to progress. That might sound tedious, but it's actually quite fun, of course there's always the internet for the ones you really can't find, something I wasn't equipped with in the '90s. Turok was a cool character and still is, and it's regretful that the series was never really revived. He doesn't say much besides screaming his name, so there's not much to talk about in that department. Later on I picked up some of the Turok comics and read some of the backstory, and apparently he's trying to stop The Campaigner from removing barrier between the lost lands and earth, so that aliens, baldheaded guys, and dinosaurs can come through.

The game is punishing as older games tend to be, but it's not impossible, and after getting back into the mindset that older game have, I was back in business. The game throws pickups at you like it's candy, probably because the console version was a lot harder to play. As the game progresses, these pickups become more necessary, and eventually the difficulty is ramped up significantly.

I finished this game in under 10 hours, but I must admit that Ive used a guide to find all the keys that I couldn't find, which was about 5. After that, I blasted my way through the final level and the boss using guides on how to beat them that made them fairly easy.

40027039.review: It's as if Quake and Crash Bandicoot had a child and named it Turok. But seriously, Turok is one of the most uniquely original FPS games I've ever played. The gameplay is smooth yet challenging, the weapons are massively fun, the maps are interesting also full of secrets, and the workshop gives it a fair amount of replayability with various mods and custom maps available so far. Overall my only cons are no multiplayer, so I'm not sure it's worth the 20 dollar price tag, however it's the only game of it's kind so if you can at least grab it on sale I'd highly recommend doing so.

39990103.review:
Turok est un FPS à l'ancienne, sorti à l'origine en 1997 sur Nintendo 64. C'est devant un écran cathodique, la manette à trois branches en main et avec mon grand frère que j'ai à l'époque pu découvrir le jeu, et c'est une vingtaine d'années plus tard que j'ai pu y rejouer dans cette réédition PC.

Cette réédition est un portage très fidèle à la version originale du jeu ; bien que les textures, effets aquatiques et contrôles aient été retapés, repensés et adaptés, on a affaire basiquement au même jeu qu'à l'époque. Si vous recherchez un FPS à l'ancienne, vous aller y trouver votre bonheur ; c'est dynamique, on fonce dans le tas, les couloirs et grands espaces qui s'alternent sont peuplés d'ennemis, de phases de plate-forme et d'énigmes pas nécessairement complexes (à moins que vous ne cherchiez à trouver tous les secrets, auquel cas vous pourrez plus amplement vous prendre la tête).

Alors oui, le jeu a vieilli, visuellement mais aussi en termes de gameplay. Les avancées des FPS modernes nous rappellent à quel point les pionniers tels DOOM, Quake ou encore ce fameux Turok étaient finalement primitifs ; mais posez-vous réellement la question, que souhaitez-vous d'un FPS?

Turok est ancien, simple et basique. Le jeu se prend en main en un rien de temps, l'interface est minimaliste, et aucune réelle cinématique ne viendra interrompre votre séance de jeu. Turok, c'est l'essence du FPS.

Si c'est ce que vous recherchez, foncez dessus. Si vous préférez les jeux modernes, Turok n'est peut-être pas fait pour vous.

39737005.review: Classic 90's console FPS remastered for the PC.You play as Tal'Set who s a time travelling warrior and the latest in the line of Turoks. The big bad is known as the Campaigner and he wants to get hold of the Chronoscepter, a weapon so powerful it was broken down into to 8 pieces to stop it falling into the wrong hands. It's your job as Tal'Set to collect the chronoscepter first and put a stop to the Campaigner.  You don't actually need to collect the Chronoscepter pieces but it certainly makes the last boss battle easier. The basic premise is never expanded upon and basically serves as an excuse for blasting a whole lot of enemies, but a good arsenal, some solid gunplay and the fast pace keep things moving along nicely.  I found some of the levels to be a bit too long especially the last one and the over reliance on platforming sections does begin to grate a bit by the end. Saving is done via a combination of checkpoints and save points scattered about the levels and these can be quite far apart meaning one missed platform jump can lead to having to replay a large section of the level over again. The polished up graphics hold up quite well considering this is a game that's over 20 years old and the music and sound effects are pleasing. The basic mechanics of key hunting are systematic of the title's age although i never found this to be problematic. It took me around 9 hours to complete on normal difficulty, that included finding all the chronscepter pieces and for the most part it's a great ride and definately worth playing!

39703278.review: had it along time ago on n64 when i was a kid. i decided to buy it on here and its pretty much a better version compared to n64. frame rate is smooth and everything is sharp and detailed

39691653.review:
Do you like 1st-person jumping puzzles? And, I don't just mean jumping between platforms. There's alot of platforms, and there are quite a few walls. Walls that you have to jump against until you reach the top. Oh, and you can't just mash jump. You have to time it, like you'd have to in a 3rd person platformer. Only, as I mentioned, this game is 1st person.

The jumping puzzles, especially the ones where you have to jump against a wall for 5 minutes, would be extremely easy if you could see the avatar as a reference. Without that reference, the extremely punishing "challenge" comes down entirely to timing when you hit a key for several minutes. It's the Stanley Parable "Art" ending drawn out for an entire game. 

And, falling sometimes kills you instantly. And, there's a lives system. And, maps are mazes filled with too many dead ends, hitscan enemies, and fog.

Turok is not a game that I consider to be fun at all. The lack of a targeting reticle is interesting, and fighting enemies is engaging, but I had to turn "Fly" on in order to bypass several extremely frustrating jumping sections. I highly suggest anyone who values their time leave this "classic" in the dust.

Unless, of course, the Stanley Parable "Art" ending was fun to you. It's not hard; some people just find it to be too frustrating/boring to bother with.

39682149.review:
You ever catch yourself thinking "what if you threw two or three things that are, y'know, like, ultra-cool, and I'm not talking just 'alright cool', like, ULTRA cool: Native American warriors and dinosaurs and aliens and sci-fi and jungles..."? Well, Turok is just that. And it works!

The boys at Night Dive have done a fantastic job bringing this game back to life - visually, it's a 90s shooter all the way, for better or for worse. Since this was originally an N64 game, it doesn't quite have the crisp texturework of something like the Build engine games or Quake, but it still has a very appealing and coherent art-style that somehow manages to explore varied environments that never feel out of place. You have your standard jungle complete with volcanic areas, treetop villages and an alien ship final level. Sound design is very solid, the gun sounds are a bit airy but the energy weapons and the bow feel fantastic.

Gameplay is also quality stuff. You have your standard keyhunting and exploration of non-linear levels, only Turok takes it up a notch a la HeXen and adds a hub level. The cool thing is that each level requires three keys to unlock, and you can choose which level to play, provided you have the keys to unlock it. This means you can enter and exit levels almost at will (you have to find the exit, but once you do, you can choose another level). Fortunately, the key locations are fairly sequential meaning you won't have level 8 keys in level 2 or level 6 keys in level 3. What this does mean, however, is that resource management and picking your battles is absolutely paramount for success because A) some enemies respawn when you re-enter the level and B) you WILL be revisiting the same level a few times, especially if you want to find all the secrets. Respawning enemies can be annoying, but personally I prefer this mechanic over endless wandering in empty maps. My only complaint in terms of pacing is that the very last level does drag on just a bit too long, which given the game's length makes sense, but after all that keyhunting, the last thing you'd expect is three quite sizeable levels before the final bossfight. Also, there's a save point and checkpoint mechanic (no quicksaves), which might extend the playtime in a way that's not particularly fun, but it does add some tension to the gameplay even if it might feel a bit relentless at times.

The gunplay is also deep and engaging, the weapons are varied, satisfying and balanced well and ammo/health distribution is masterful. Again, respawning ammo would have been a good idea because if you're not careful, you'll be running around with no ammo really quickly, but this is just a testament to the fact that older games trusted the player to know what the hell they were doing. There are numerous enemy types with various attack patterns and a good mix between projectile, melee and hitscan enemies... I could go on and on, but the bottom line is, the whole thing gels like Jack and Coke and it's a blast to play.

The only thing I can really complain about is perhaps the price, at 19.99€ it's a bit pricey for an old title, even with the amazing remaster, and it's not really that horribly long at that; achievements and secrets do give it some replay value, but if you're not sure if you want to pull the trigger on this one or not, try waiting for a sale, I think it's definitely worth 10€, 20€ might be a stretch.

In short, this game is a fairly unique classic and should not be overlooked by FPS fans and gamers in general. Robot dinosaurs, man!!!
